element_texts.text: Completed

Hudson Aug 3/70  Dear Cousin. Allow me to introduce to you our friend and brother Mr Kendall from Illinois.  He with his family have been stopping with us a little while, and now he is seeking a house in the West, or South — that is more favorable to his health.  I think he would be interested in what you might say regarding Minnesota.  Please to give him the benefit of your long experience there.  Mr Reed would like very much to make this trip with Mr. Kendall but I hardly think he will do so.  He has a very great regard for your State and would like to live there
Completed

Mother is now quite sick at Sister Taft’s in Keene.  We are fearful that she will be no better.  Her disease was Dysentery. and she does not seem to recover from it as we were hoping she would.  Mrs Bassett is with her.  I hope next time you come East, we may have a visit from you.  Love to Mrs Gale, Dulcina and the other cousins.  Mr Reed wishes to be kindly remembered to you, Cousin Rhoda G Reed
Completed

Feb 25th 1855
[to Nathan - Areli Stedman]
Dear Brother
It has been a long long 
time since I wrote to you or to any one else 
I have had a [fellon?] on my first finger on my 
right hand I suffered a good deal with it, but 
it has got most swell now but is quite tender 
yet, I was down home about two weeks ago 
had a very pleasant time while there Libbie 
and I received your very welcome letter 
but I was sorry to learn that you are going 
so far from us. What can we do without 
you? Indiana is a very dear place to me because 
that was our dear Jossie's home she lived and 
died there. I do hope you will conclude that 
it is best for you not to go to Nebraska 
if you should go, do not think of going without 
coming home for sure all want to see you
[written along the left-hand side of the page]
My sheet is nearly full so I shall have to stop. this is written so badly I don't 
know as you can read it but my finger is quite weak so that I tremble
but I wanted to write to you so much I commenced as soon as I could 
for this is the second letter I have
written for more than five weeks
I wrote home Friday and am going
to write to all my correspondents
soon. I will not ask any question
about yourself for you will tell 
them with out. I must speak
of our Sunday school. we have a very
large one for us. [Mr. Berron?]
superintends it. I am very much
interested in it. I am in Sister
Marg's class we have forty dollars
of new books of the very
best kind. When you write tell
me all about Mr. [illegible] folks
Lydia, and all your brothers
I want to tell you what I have
been reading. Dream Life it is a
kind of a novel but a very good
one. History of Josephine and
Madam Ballard I read last I think
them very interesting I would
write more about what I have
been reading if I had room
now do write to me very
soon for I do want to know
how your health is and what
you are going to do. come home
if you can 
from your
affectionate sister
Areli
Completed

I am asked about you almost every day. 
I hope soon to hear from you that I can 
tell them about you. Fanny Chappell stayed 
with me last night. we talked much about 
Jossie and you. she sends her best respects to you. 
Hellen [Regnior?] speaks often of you. she wanted 
to come up to day and write some in my letter 
to you but she had a bad cold and thought she 
had better not come out. Mr. Barron preaches 
us very excellent searmons every Sunday. I think t
hey get better and better every time. we have 
most a housefull every time he preaches. he is 
liked much by the most of them. Mr. Franks 
[Boathe Regnior?] would not go to hear him 
for any thing. they don't think him a good 
man. I don't like him as a man very well 
but I do like to hear him preach. Mr. Ward is 
going to build a Unitarian church. I think 
a great many will go there for they great times 
in all the churches. they dont agree at all. 
O. F. Clark has got to be a regular attendant at 
our church. I guess he has given up infidelity. 
Mr. Holden has again reformed. he attends church 
most of the time and does Mrs. Holden 
[Mrs Clara's?] folks like Mr. Barron but they 
hardly ever go to church but usually attend the
Completed

dancing parties at the hall every live week there  I unknown like the Barron.  The Barron " says he thinks the atmosphere must be had upon the hill" and I have almost come to that conclusion by the way the people act that live there.  We had a donation party atMr. Barrens Friday ensuring there was most a house full there.  they some nice presents and we had a very pleasant still time, I wish Jan could have been there  I think Jan would have enjoyed it much.  Last week I spen a day with Mrs Breithe?, we talked over old Institute affairs, she seemed to feel badly that any one should say to Jan that she had had enough of the Kendall's for she is sure she never said it. She dont think Mr Halden is a man of his word.  she spoke very affectionly of Jan and said if there ever was any one a gentleman she though Jan was onel.  she wished me to write to you about it and to be rembered to you.  She wants to see you much.   Melda B.Smith has a daughtr they are going to live in Pomeroy.  I guess Jan will know all about the Marietta people when you read this letter for I have spoken of it many.  Mr Braughteon also, wishes to be rembered to Jan.  He often asks about your
Completed

Father and Mother are unclear their ages this Winter they are so much better than they have been  Mother is in very good spirits she enjoys life now I think quite as well if not better than at any other time in her life. she is trying all the time to do something for LIbbie's and my interest. she would like to have me with her this winter but thinks that it is necessary for me to learn how to sew it has not hurt me any yet and I think will not.  I shall not stay after two months unclear.  I am enjoying the Winter very much . Sister Mary is better this Winter than she was in the Summer. Sister E? and Willy are well.  we had a letter from Guss? last night she spoke of receiving your letter a short time ago she likes much to get letters from you.  Father I guess will have to pay George's debt in the Spring I think it too bad but he can't get along with business affairs. I pity Sister Guss?to think she will always live in poverty.  I have had many urgeant invitations to teach where I did in unclear next Spring. there is a gentleman wants me to teach in his family, but I rather think I shall remain at home next Summer.  and let Libbie come and go to Mr. Lenny? they have a pretty good school considering.
Completed

Center Belpre July 22nd 55
Dear Brother Your long looked for letter has arrived, I had not heard from you for so long I was fearful you was sick. but I guess you will be a well man yet.I am happy to hear of such bright prospects as you have before you. I hope you can keep your situation but I do want you to come home, but I will wait longer. We are all quite well, Mother is much better than she has been, dad are getting along well with the farm this year, we have an abundance of fruit of every variety wish you could come and help us eat some of our large scarlet apples and peaches and we have a splendid garden too. As I have several other letters to write I will close hoping to hear from you very soon Your sister Areli
Completed

They have a new preacher in Marietta Mr unclear he is a young man has a wife they all think he speaks as you do and is very much like you. He cannot preach perhaps as well as Mr Barron but they think him a much better man. Mr Barron is still living in Marietta and has a circuit, ne preaches here and at the unclear of Hoecking and unclear and several other places though there are but few that like him as a man here. Mr Seat is teaching in the institute yet, I guess it will never be raised up again but the church is doing well. I have seen and heard of several of the Institutions lately, Mr Grier was here a few days ago he has been going to school since he left Marietta he is studying law and practised some, he says Jassie advised him to be a lawyer and he thought so much of her he took her advise O.J. Clark is also studying unclear, he was down with Mr Grier, they enquired particularly about your health unclear
Completed

I have spent very much time of late reading the Bible. I never could make it interesting until recently but now it is a a pleasure to read it and I find it the most interesting of all books, the more I read the more I wonder? than any one can believe the bible and preach the doctrine of endless punishment. I have been reading Balfours explanation of the word hell and have learned? much from it. I have been committing many chapters to memory.  It is with Lizzie now as it was with me when I was of her age, she says she can't think of such things and does not want to read the Bible.  I have seen the books that you spoke of and intend reading them. I want to read all the time and think I never would get tire but I have many other duties to perform so that I to not read as much as I ought. Augusta and George are giving up talk of going out to Kansas this fall  George is now contented and will always be a poor man I do pity sister and wish she could live with
Completed

Stedman to N. + Jos Kendall
Woodstock 31st March 1854
My Dear Children I started from home just one week after Elizabeth did + came down on the same boat and arrived here on Saturday morning + found them in good health + waiting for my arrival. I need not say there glad to see me, I went down the next morning to see my little farm, + was much pleased with it. I got the deed + have got it recorded + think the place is worth one thousand dollar, the folks where I left house were as well as usual. unclear had got through with her school + got her money. I caught a violent cold a few days before I started + was quite unwell on the way, but feel much better indeed as niece Augusta is going home with me  with her little Mary who is a very sweet child Augusta is very sorry that she is not going to see Lib before she returns we think some of starting home this afternoon we all send love + good will. + I expect when I get home to hear whether Elizabeth arrived safe in Peru? or not
as I am not in the habit of writing you will excuse this short letter
Yours affectionately
Brink Stedman
Completed

Mr. N Kendall
Peru
Indiana
Mother Stedman to? unclear
Completed

[n.d.]
Centre Belpre Ohio, Sep. 16th 
My dear Brother, 
For fear you have forgotten 
to write or forgotten us.  I will just 
write you a little to remind you 
of us such? that - you owe us no less 
than three letters! Why don't you 
write to us + I have been so busy 
lately that I have not had time to 
write letters, though I can always 
find time to read them. We are 
very busy drying fruit.  Have had 
men working for us &c so that I 
have been obliged to stay at home 
from school and help, as we cannot 
get a girl. I went the first week 
but cannot go any more.  I have 
no time to spare to read or unclear unclear 
unclear ride horse back unclear the
Completed

evening. unclear and hand each of us a two year old colt, riding skirts and cap and once? off? we go every evening. We have a kind man that broke our colts for us and he has to go with us because the colts "act up" sometimes.  Mr. Edwards and his wife are at home now.  and Mrs. Learing? is sick  has a very poor girl unclear of her girls have gone to Cincinnati to school.  Delia goes to the "unclear High School",  unclear goes to Mr. unclear  unclear Charlotte and Mary have both been down this Summer and made long visits. I wish you were here to help me eat our nice peaches. for have we have so many we do not know what to do with them all. They are very [[small?] this year. but rather sweet.  I expect Mr. unclear will preach here to weeks from today.  We are all very glad for we have not heard any preaching for so long, unclear unclear unclear graces? unclear unclear word I write so I'll stop. 
write to us very soon, from Sister Lizzie
Completed

Centre Belpre Sept 17 [1854]
My dear Brother, 

We received your last letter on Wed-

nesday and were very glad as ever to hear from you, 
glad to hear that you were well, that you were 
doing well, and that you were coming home. 
I am also glad that you have received one of the 
many letters I have written you. Though it was 
written some time since, my teeth have got about 
well but as soon as I take a little cold they ache 
again. 'fis so very unpleasant -  
I spoke of writing you a French letter. I hardly 
have time now for we are so busy drying fruit 
and have so many travelers that my time is 
nearly all occupied. and it would take me 
longer to write a French letter than this one 
so you will have to wait a while. I will 
finish this tomorrow when I hear from 
Gus and George. Sunday 24th. I have waited 
a whole week and received no letters from 
any one either. It is too bad. Mother is 
quite unwell with a sore ear. it is swollen 
and very sore and aches all the time night 
and day.  I fear she will be obliged to give up
Completed

her visit to Woodstock on that account.  Besides 
the water is so low there is but one boat goes on 
the Muskingum. I don't think I ever enjoyed better 
health than I have this Fall. though 
I am very lonely. Just Father Mother and I here all alone 
all the time. Areli is not good to write to us at 
all though I have written her quite frequently. Father 
found our colt last week and a pretty one she is too  
She will be two years old next Spring and she is 
as large as two year old now. Father says he would 
not take fifty-dollars for it now. wont I have 
some nice rides when it gets large enough though?  
Our peaches are most gone. only one more tree of cling 
stones, have had so many peaches as we waited to 
eat this Summer and that is more than we expected. 
Have you had any to eat? Aunt Polly expects to start 
from Steubenville in a short time she has made her 
last visit here. She went to Mr Putnams but 
did not like her visit there at all.  was not treated 
well she says.  Do you hear from Areli or any of the rest 
of the folks? They don't write home any more. I don't know 
but they have forgotten how to write. Mr. Bailey's 
folks expect to move to the West as soon as 
they can sell.  Nearly all of our neighbors are going 
to leave so that we shall have new ones soon.  Do you 
hear from your brothers and sisters in St. Louis? if 
so how are they all getting along? Has Myron's leg got 
well?  Has Mrs. Weaver recovered her health yet? How's 
Miss Kendall got through with her school year?  
Shan't I be glad though when you and Areli come 
home? Will you come before she does? 
This is but a short uninteresting letter but in 
fact there is nothing to write you will please 
excuse it would you? Mr Putnam's people had a dry 
house and a quantity of dried fruit in it burned 
down last week.  They don't know it 
took fire.  You must hurry home and help 
us eat our own sweet potatoes from we shall begin 
to use them soon.  Write soon to your
Sister Libbie
Completed

[1854? 5?]
[(Eliz Stedman)]
Centre Belpre Oct 8
My dear Brother
I received a letter from you yesterday dated 
Sept 28th and was right glad to get it for we had not 
heard from you for a long, long time. I am real 
sorry you are having such a fuss and advise 
you to come away from there for fear of gete
ting hurt. besides I am very lonesome here now 
and would like to have you come and keep us 
company.  Areli's school continues some weeks 
longer and then she will come, but if you won't 
come before that time I shall surely go off.  
I received a letter from Areli yesterday and would 
send it to you if I thought you could read it 
and she would not care.  but I fear she will so 
I will just do as she told me to, tell you 
what was in it, she is not going to 
write to you or Gus and George till she gets 
home, for she has not time to write only Sunday 
I believe she said, and that time she was 
going to spend in writing home. she writes 
to us very seldom but almost quite cheerful 
when she does write.  I told her she must write 
to you for I knew you would be glad to hear 
[written along the left-hand side of the page]
They want you to 
come fast to the
Institute and teach
at Marietta and 
say if you come
home this [illegible] 
they will make 
you teach. I
told Mr. [Barry?]
your health would
not permit. He
said you must
get well and then 
teach. Please
excuse this short
poorly written 
letter from
your sister
Lib
Please excuse 
me I forgot to
put this in the
office [illegible]
yesterday
Completed

from her. I have not heard from Gus and George
a great while I can't imagine the reason they don't
write. Sister Mary and Charlotte both well as usual
I intend going up to the Fair and Marietta next
Friday. Mother has not given up going to [road?]
[illegible] yet. she seems to want to go very much
A Mrs. Catherine Nye and little daughter died in
Marietta of the Flu last week. they are relatives
of Mr. Putnam's folks. Did you get the Marietta paper
I sent you with [illegible] Clarks Marriage in it?
We have received several Tribunes that you sent
us but none for a week or two past. I was
fifteen years old last Friday, did not get but
one present, what Father gave me, a gold dollar.
I got lots of whippings. the dog and cat you inquired
of are fast well, though we think of having the old
cat killed for he is so troublesome, he is such a thief
I don't have much chance to ride any so the old horse
gets more rest than she used to. Father found
his colt the other day and it is such a pretty one
it will be fit for me to ride next spring
then I shall have some nice rides. I thought
you wrote some time ago that David had
gone back to New England, but I see by your
last that he is in Pen yet. Do you hear from
St. Louis? M McKay's folks sent us two pail's
full of nice sweet cider yesterday, so of course I am
drunk. There are two [Stears?] Boats on the far down
here and have been for a long time and I guess will
be for another long time. Have you got any tomb
stairs for Jossie yet and have you the lot fixed
yet as you intended to have it done? Do you visit
her grave often? and does the Grave yard look as prettily
now as it did when I was there? you know there
were such pretty thick woods around it. Please excuse
me for writing with a pencil but there is no good
pen in the house. Write very soon and tell me
when you are coming home from your sister Lib
Completed

Oct 29th 1854
My dear Brother
It has been a very long time
since I have written a word to you, but I know
you will not scold me when I tell you the reason
I took mother up to Marietta a week ago last Thursday
morning. she got on a boat Friday morning, got
to Woodstock Saturday night and here I am
at home all alone with Father and Willie. 
I can tell you I have found plenty to do since
Mother left. It seems as though all the travelers
know what Mother is gone and want to come
to bother me, for I never knew so many before.
I received a letter from Gus and George Friday
they said brother got there safe and was in
very good spirits and health. when she went
away she said she was only going to stay
three weeks but Gus says she is not going to
let her come home this winter. I do hope she
will enjoy herself while she stays. she is having
beautiful weather now. I hope it will last so as
long as she stays. I received a letter from Areli
Wednesday and one from Sister Abby Monday.
Completed

she sends her best respects to you. She is very well
and working as hard as she can. [Loll?] says "only
four weeks more then the good time is coming"
for her school will be out then. she says she
does not get time to write to anyone only to home
so I suppose she has not written you yet. They want
her to stay all winter but she will not do it. She
is enjoying herself very well indeed.
If you wanted to get a school here this winter
you could get one large enough to fill our big barn
for every person I see says "is Mr. Kendall coming
home this winter? how soon is he coming? I
heard he was going to have a school and I thought
I would like to go to him." I tell them I don't know.
I have been to [illegible] evening parties a few weeks
since one at Mr [Learnings?] the other at Miss Ames'. had
a very please time both places. Miss Julia Putnam
and George Wilcox are to be married next month.
Mrs. Putnam says. I think it is most time for
Julia is getting pretty old - I don't know where I
can go to school this winter for there is none to
go to. They have not engaged a teacher up here
yet. if they get a good one I may go there or else
I'll have to stay at home. There have been two
large balls in Marietta at the "Meladean Hall"
Completed

(Sister Charlotte's new building by Mr Baldwins)
Sister Charlotte attended both of them. I have not
seen her since the last one which was last week.
She is getting to be quite young in her "old age."
I like to dance, and I don't know as there is any
harm in it. though it does often times lead to
harm. There are a great many people around here
that have the Flux. There have three died with
it within two weeks, and many others are sick
with it. I do wish you could come home this winter
it will be so lonely here if you don't for I expect some
of the family will be gone, then I am so lonesome.
I have made [illegible] cheese since mother left aint
I smart though? I do as much work as mother and I
did together, some time, when I have lots to do. there
will five or six travelers come for dinner or to
stay all night and supper and breakfast then I have
to jump around I tell you. I am lots smarter than
I used to be. I am getting as fat as I can be, so you
see hard work agrees with me. There was a man
here yesterday that wants to buy our farm and per-
haps he may, though he thinks we ask too much
for it. I don't want to sell one single bit, but
mother rand Father do. Mother wants to by a larger
farm out near our "little one" but Father does not.
Completed

The 24th of this month was Jossie's birth day. if she
had lived she would have been 22 years old.
but she has left us only six months ago. it seems to
me but yesterday - I asked Willie what I should tell
you for him. he said "tell him I am down to Grand
pa's playing as hard as I can all the time." He is a
pretty good boy though dont like to mind overly well
although he does it.  He would come down home with
me. there was no keeping him at home.
How often do you visit Peru? have you got Jossie's
grave fixed yet? please tell me about it the next time
you write. When Areli comes home we are going up to
Marietta to make a visit together. if it is pleasant
weather. I guess you or I will have to go up that French
letter. I commenced writing it last week but it was such
slow work and so hard I had not time to finish it,
so I stopped.
I have three or four more letters to write today
so I guess I shall have to stop. for I can [illegible]
nothing to write. but please write to us soon
for if you don't we think you are sick. and if 
you were. there is no good Jossie to write to us
as often as she used to and tell us when she
was sick or well. you asked me long time ago
if I would not try and get [illegible] that bad
Jossie's death in it but I have not as yet completed
with your request but will do so soon as I can
write soon and excuse all mistakes from
your affectionate sister Libbie Stedman
Completed

Centre Belpre Nov 12nd 1854
My dear Brother:
I will write you a few words this evening for I know you will
want to know how mother got home and the rest the news.
She came home from Gus' last Friday, she is well except a cold, she had a very good time and left
all the folks well. They hated to have her come away, but she thought
she had stayed long enough and so came home. she stayed three weeks. I was right glad
to have her come. I did very well while she was gone. Mother brought
me a new dress from Marietta. it is so pretty I think I will send
you a piece of it. it cost eighty seven and a half cents a yard
I am going to wait till I go to Marietta with [Loll? Sall?] before I have
it made. only two more weeks of Areli's school. O. I am so glad.
When she comes we are going to Marietta to make a visit.
We all think it will cost [illegible] for me to go out there to
school. I would like to go so much. Monday morning. I expect I shall have to
go here to Hanmar this winter. school commences two
weeks from today. mother, Father, and I went down to Mr.
Lewis' last night to see Mrs. Lewis' sister. she is a Healing
Medium. does not or cannot talk any while under the spiritual influence
Completed

She answers questions by motions. She became influenced
while we were there and we asked if it was Jossie's spirit.
she clapped her hands very hard for yes. She then went round
to all that were present and [shook?] hands, and kissed mother
and hugged her very hard. we asked her if Jossie was
happy. she clapped her hands for yes and commenced
dancing just exactly like Jossie used to. I sang for her
and she would keep time as regularly as could be. We asked
her if it was Jossie's wish that we should mind [circles?]
to which she answered yes. wanted mother to cultivate
her moral faculties more. and said that I would
become a speaking medium. All present were moved
to tears. she bid us wipe them away and commenced
shouting and trying to sing. This lady knew nothing about
any of us, nor did not know we had lost a sister. She
has her eyes shut all of the time for she cannot open
them. She says she never feels so happy in all of her
life as when under this influence. I think it is very
strange, but I do know there is no deception in
it. They are not making money at it and what good
could it do to try to deceive? Her husband went up to the
school house yesterday and preached a very good Universalist
sermon. there were very many there from other denominations
Completed

and all liked it very much, but if it had gone under
that name then would have but few attended. They are not
very smart, learned people but have good common sense
and I believe they are good people and try to do good.
let it be spiritualist or what it is, so it does good
what is the difference? I have never heard of its doing
any harm. I would have gave all I posses to have had you
there last night whether you believe or not. It certainly
is very strange. What shall I study this winter? only the
ones I did last winter. Geography Grammar Arithmetic Reading
Writing. There are none here that study Algebra. I have not time
to write any more this morning, nor much more to [illegible].
I do wish you could come home this winter but wishing
will do no good. mother said that Augusta sent you the
[Star?] that had Jossie's death in it, so I will not do it.
Brother George is not doing well. he does not stick to
one thing long enough. he is around peddling mutton
now. I guess they don't think of moving I guess for they did
not say any thing about it. Mother likes our little place
out there very much. all the rest of the family have
been there and the next time is my turn.
Write soon to us. Loll has not written to one single
person but [illegible] since she left. from your Sister Libbie [Stedman]
I weigh one hundred and ten pounds!
Completed

[Lizzie Stedman to N. Kendall]
Centre Belpre, O. Feb 9th 1855
My dear Brother:
We received your letter yesterday that told us that you
thought of going to Nebraska. We all feel sorry to think you are going
so far away, but if you think it is for your own good to go we cannot
keep you back. You must come home and make us a good large visit
before you go any how. O. you must not go, for I cannot hear from
you so often for it will take the letters so long to come. then I shall think
of you as being in some wild place among Indians and uncivilized
people. and you will not enjoy yourself half so well there as here. I
would not go even if I could make myself. better off, as to riches.
It is such good sleighing now that we of course have a good deal of
company. Areli came down with Will Marshall Wednesday, and nearly a dozen
more young folks. we went up to Mr. Putnam's in the evening and had
a pleasant time. Areli could not go for she has a [felon?] on her finger
and it pained her so at night that she stayed at home with
Father and Mother, Sister Mary & Charlotte, Willie and Mr. Broughton came
down yesterday in a sleigh. They went home today. We had a pleasant
time. Sister Mary's health is very good this winter.
Mr. and Mrs. Putnam have just come to spend the afternoon, so if I make
mistakes you must excuse them. I did not go to school today for
I had to assist mother. She is very well now, but we have so much
company
Completed

I do not study anything but Arithmetic and Grammar. I hated to stop
Algebra, but [illegible] thought me did not understand "Extracting the [illegible]
Root" well enough to go any farther. We are getting along well in Arithmetic and
Grammar, are most through the latter. School will be out in three
weeks and I think we shall get through the Arithmetic too.
I did not answer the letter you wrote before the last. I sent
it up to Areli to answer, but her finger has been so sore that she
could not do anything. I thought she had answered it and that is
the reason that I did not write before this.
It is time to make the fire for supper, so I must stop. -
Now that I've got through with supper I will try and
write some more. Mr. and Mrs. Putnam inquired of you
and Mr. Putnam especially in regard to your health. They
hear from Julia every week and sometimes twice a week.
She is well and enjoys herself much where she is. Lottie and
Gus Curtis went down to Cincinnati before this freeze and
have not or cannot get home yet. She took the youngest
with her, and left the other two at home with the hired girl.
I think she must be crazy to do such a thing as that.
The letter before the last that you wrote you dated it 1853. gone
back have you? It is nice weather now the ground is nearly ice.
Two years ago the 22nd of this month or dear sister Jossie
was with us. anticipating all the pleasures that this life
affords us for it was her wedding day. but she is not with us 
now. I have thought of her so much today and yesterday. all the
sisters and friends came down from Marietta to see us, but
there is no Jossie to come with them. I do miss her so much
more in the winter than any other time. We must think of her often.
Completed

Now you must be sure and come home before you go to
"out-of-the-world" I was going to say, but I mean to Nebraska.
if you don't you must write so soon as you get there, and
let me know where to direct to, but you will come home I know
before you go away, won't you? write first as soon as you get
this to let us know what you are going to do. I think
you are wild to go away off so far.
Is Mr. Gleason married yet? There is a traveler here now that looks
so much like him that I was on the point of saying "how do
you do Mr. Gleason" to him. he is just as tall and looks so
much like him. my teeth have not ached any for so long a time
that I am almost inclined to think they are going to stop for good.
I guess I have scared them for if they were do ache again I shall by
all means have them pulled out if it is my front. I don't
care for good looks, for when I have them pulled out I can have
some more put in. I do not know about Mr. Holden, the
folks stayed so short a time that I did not hardly have
time to say anything. Mr. Marshall I guess is all the talk now-
a-days with his new wife. She is twenty-four years old and he
forty eight. that's "going it while you're old" is'nt it?
The children all call her Sarah, Mr. Marshall told the little girls to
call her mother and they both burst right out crying. so he never said
anything more to them. Mother is commencing you another pair of
socks. I would come home to get them if for nothing else.
We hear from Sister Abby often. She always speaks of you, and
expects you to make a visit next summer.
Our parties will be grand for [Loll?] and I to ride next summer.
You must come home and help us, we will have nice times.
Completed

I will send you the last "Columbian" and ["Intelligiver"?]. It seems 
they are going to try to have a "Unitarian Society" in Marietta by the Marietta 
paper. I have thought I would send you the Columbian every 
week but have neglected to do so, and this time I will send it.
I have written you about all the news and that is all I can write 
so you must be sure to write soon.  Excuse all mistakes and 
accept much love from your sister 
Lizzie
Completed

Centre Belpre, O. Feb 25, 1855
My dear Brother,
It has been sometime since I wrote you and some time
since you wrote to me, too, I guess. But how do you do? you have not
gone to Nebraska yet, have you? I expected to have seen you home
before this, why have you not come?
Received a letter from Areli last evening, and her finger has got
almost well, well enough to sew with. Sister Mary caught cold when
she came down here and now has the Rheumatism in her back.
The rest of us are all well. A Mrs. Carey in Marietta had a little boy
drowned last week, he was just coming home from school; and 
stopped to slide on the ice down by one of the bridges and broke
in, they did not find him till the next morning. His mother feels
very badly about it. I hope it will be a warning to the other boys, for
they are all so careless. "There was a 'Donation Party' at Mr. Barrows'
last week. I have heard nothing about it yet.
One week more of school, and then want I be lonesome? I expect I
shall go to the "Union School" in the Spring. but don't know,
Father's health is good, Mother's tolerably. I am very well, have a 
lame wrist, caused by washing Saturday. Father was sent for to
appear at court next Tuesday, but will not go. they want
him as a witness in the Sister C's and Mr Rolston's case, but
Completed

he says he does not know anything about it and is not going.
We are going to hire this summer, not rent our land as Father
thinks he can do better to hire. Mother seems low spirited. I think
because we do not get along better, she worries half the time. we owe
for her doctor bill, and that debt of George's to Sister C we
have got to pay. we have paid in fact fifty dollars of it, and
I expect will have to pay the rest and it worries her very much.
you knew when you were here that Alfred and Areli had played
"quits" did you not? but did not know the reason. I will tell you
if you will not tell her. she never has told one of us one word
about it, and the way we found it out, Sister C asked Mr.
Marshall about it and he told the whole. There was a girl went
to school to Mr. [Averill?] last winter named Rebecca Palmer, she
boarded at Mr. M's, and took a fancy for Alfred, or rather she
knew there was something between Areli and Alfred, and she
took it into her head to break it up, and she tried every possible
way to attract Alfred's attention (and that she could well do)
till Alfred got so that he was not easy one minute out
of her sight, and finally they were engaged to be married, the
day was set if you believe! Well there were some dozen folks, with
the band, were going to Cincinnati on a pleasure trip, I believe
they (the band) went without paying and each one took a lady. well, Alfred
could not go. [Bitha?] went with Will, and I believe Captain Cox took
his Miss Palmer, so Alfred told [Bitha?] to watch Miss Palmer,
and she did. And Captain Cox was very attentive to her, and
finally asked her if she was engaged, to which she replied that
she was not. So they were engaged and [Bitha?] went home and told
Alfred and then "terrible times". Beck would not go to school.
Completed

she said she was a sick, but there was nothing else the matter of her 
only this matter, and that was enough. When school was out 
Rebecca Palmer and Captain Cox were married! When Alfred asked his father about 
marrying her, his father reminded him of Areli, and told him 
that he was doing wrong, but he said that he was young then,
and now he knew better. So Areli wont have anything more to do 
with him. Now he goes to see Nancy Stowe up the  musking? 
It is so dark I cannot see the lines and as I can find nothing 
more to write and am tired I will stop. Write soon to [illegible] 
Lizzie
Completed

[L. Stedman]
Centre Belpre, O, March 11th 1855
My dearest Brother: [Nathan]
We received your letters last Friday, and I was anxiously looking 
for one, for I knew it would tell whether you were going to Nebraska or not. 
And it told me just as I wanted it to. We are all in good health, though 
I must say not in good spirits. We are going to work this farm ourselves, 
and of course have to hire, hands are very high and Father does not manage 
well. Do you hear from Gus and George? what do they write? not in good 
spirits I guess. Father has paid Sister C. part of that debt, George ought to be 
ashamed to let him, though. It was just about a year ago that I was on my 
road to Peru. What trials we have had to go through in the past year, I 
can not bear to think it is so. it seems but a dream yet it is real. Jossie little 
thought then, how soon she would be called away. 
I have just written thwo letters one to Sisters at Marietta one to Sarah [Gunnar?]
in Ills. and have two more to write besides this one, to Sister Abby, and to 
Gus & George. I have a library book I want to read too, but dont know as I shall 
get time. We have a share in the library now, so that I can get all kinds 
of books I want to read. I dont know as I shall write you much of a 
letter, but I will do the best that I can. There are no news, and that is 
all I have to depend upon in writing a letter. Jerry Bennet is going to 
teach a select school up the road this Spring, and I dont know but they 
will send me to that. I had rather go to Marrietta, but I dont know 
which place I would learn the most. [Mr. Learning's?] two girls are going to 
Mr. Bennet, Our school was out two weeks ago last Friday. I was glad.
Completed

Areli is still in Marietta I do not know when she will come home, I
would like to have her come so soon as she can, for I am so lonesome.
It is so dark and cloudy that I can hardly see to write. Addie Bliggard
Smith has a little daughter a month old to care for. they hear from them
often. Julia Putnam's husband was at home a few weeks ago because on
business and stayed but a short time. There are several sick around here
with the Mumps and Typhus Fever. I never had the mumps.
The river is up nearly even with the banks so that the boats run like every
thing. We have a boy living with us now. he is a very good boy. Why can't you
come home? I am very sorry that you feel so poor that you can't make us a visit
Just leave for a little while then run back, can't you? Do you hear from your
sisters and brothers in St. Louis and elsewhere?
I expect Father will have my cold "broke" this week, then for some
nice rides. I went up to school last Friday up the road, it was the
last day. I had not a very good time. Archy McKay that live across
the road here got so drunk last Sunday that he did not get over it till
yesterday, or he has stayed in the house all the time since till yesterday.
some of the neighbors talk of "taking him up" for it, but I think he
has suffered enough now without doing anything more to him.
I don't think the snow stayed on as long here as it did there, though it
was on longer than I ever knew of to be before, we had ground sleighing.
I have not had the tooth-ache for a long, long time, and I hope
I may never have it again, if I do I will never have it but once
more, for I'll have them out. I must stop, this is a short uninteresting
letter I know, but I could not help it. Maybe I shall feel more
like writing next time. Don't forget, or delay writing to me very
often. Accept much love from your Sister Lizzie Stedman
Completed

Centre Belpre, Jan 21st 1855
My dear brother: [Nathan]
As we have not heard from you for so long
I thought I must write to you to get you to answer and
tell us how you are. It has been more than four weeks
since we heard from you
Mother's health is much better than it was in the fore-
part of the winter. The rest of us (Father and I) are all well.
I have the tooth-ache about half of the time. I went up
to the Doctor's to have them pulled and his instruments
were broken, so that I did not have them out. But as soon
as I can I shall have them out. Areli is with Sisters in
Marietta. She will stay all winter. It is rather lonesome
here without her, though I go to school and do not mind 
it so much. I am getting along well in my studies.
I attend Bookkeeping school two evenings in a week, like
it very much. I went to church today. Will Marshall
Dudley Deval and Ivin West were there. I don't know
but Will is going to take Ena next Spring. That is the talk.
[written along the left-hand side of the page]
And as far as, or almost  -
to Equations in Algebra
I have learned a great
deal this winter.
Our "Green Peaches" we
wrote you about turned 
out to be as sour as
vinegar. that was too
bad when we had
taken so much pains
will then. Mother has
been piecing a quilt while
she finished yesterday it is
real pretty. She has got
another pair of socks
nearly done for you.
Please write to us
very soon. from
your sister
Lizzie
[Stedman]
Completed

How did you spend New Year's and Christmas? pleasantly
as I did I hope. I went to a party Christmas, and New Year's
spent the evening at one of our neighbor's as it was too muddy
to go to the party I had an invitation to.
We received a letter from Sister Abby a few days since. they were
all well. Sends her best respects to you and inquires if you
don't talk of visiting them, would be happy to have you
do so. Heard from Gusto also. they are all well. did not write
much. I had a little evening party a few days before [Loll?]
left. had a pleasant time.
Areli is not very punctual in answering letters not so much
so as she used to be. I believe I have written you twice
since I have received a letter from you. It can't be that
you have fogotten us, can it? Write to us very soon.
I heard from Marrieta last week. All the folks well. Cathy
Franks nearly got three of her fingers broken in trying
to put down a window, it came down so fast that she
could not hold it and smashed her fingers. it made
three dents in the window, it came with such force.
Cathie has a little sister with which she is much pleased.
I have some examples I must do and I am getting
sleepy so I shall have to stop. have you heard that
Mr. John Marshall is married to a Miss [Hinton?] of Marietta?
Such is the fact. don't forget to write to us very soon.
Father is very well this winter. I have grown so that
[written along the left-hand side of the page]
you would hardly know me. I weigh one hundred and twelve pounds!
I have got almost through Grammar. Am as far as "Interest" in Arithmetic.
Completed

[Libbie]
Centre Belpre Aug 21st 1855
My dear good brother.
I am here all alone just now and nothing
to do but write you a letter in answer to yours of
the 10th. Areli left home for Pameroy last Friday
to stay three or four weeks on a visit. she may stay
longer and take a school but does not know yet
Mother was sent for a few moments ago to help
make a shroud for a little child named George
[Goodnae?] who got scalded a few days ago. His Mother
(step mother) had scalded over some brine and set 
it on the floor to cool and he fell into it and
scalded himself very badly we heard from him Friday
and he was getting better but died this morning.
They live the first house on the upperside of the
road at the upper end of the apple rows. perhaps you
remember the house. There is a great deal of sickness
around here. Cholera marks and Flu (I don't know
how to spell it) Mr. McKay the [illegible] man has had
the Flux very badly but is getting much better now.
Maria and Cathy Franks and Sarah Booth came down
here a week ago Friday and Maria stayed till
Completed

Friday and the other girls till yesterday. we had a very
pleasant time visiting, riding, working, and playing &c [illegible]
I have had the tooth-ache and swollen face ever since
last Monday morning. My face was swollen wholly that
I could scarcely open my mouth to eat or speak for
two or three days Mother thinks I have the Lerafola
my nose bled a great quantity yesterday. but I think
it is nothing but the hateful, mean tooth-ache.
Father's knee is quite lame again. Mother's health is
quite good and I am just [illegible] as I took [physic?]
last night. I feel some better today. We have not
read much in the [Lestawent?] of late from the fact that
there have been so many people here. We have nothing
but travelers from morning till night. One day
last week when the girls were here we all got
ready Mr. [illegible's] girls too to go and see Callie
Sparrowhawk then nine travelers came for dinner
and that stopped our going. So that we have
read but very little only as far as [park?]. I shall
therefore defer answering your questions till I have
read far enough to find anything about them.
I can answer some of them now but will wait
(I'll not forget them) till I read farther with your
permission. I think [illegible] is a very interesting book
very many good things there to be learned.
Completed

I have not heard anything said about starting
the Institute. Mr Barron I believe intends to stay
as long as he agreed to. I have just been out to see if
I could find ripe peach or two but no such good
luck yet. We had very many nice sweet apples but
are all gone now. We hear from Sister Abbie after
she had a pleasant time going met Mr Greene at
N.Y. had a pleasant visit then found all well at 
home. All the people are well in Marietta. have
not heard from Woodstock very lately. I am sorry
they talk of leaving there. they have said nothing to us
about it yet. I think we shall have a pleasant time
this next winter when you come home. We shall expect
you and all want you to come very much. if Jossie
were with you to come too. but why wish her back
I am forgeting I would not be so evil as to have
her come from her "Heavenly Home" where all is joy
and bliss, to gratify my wishes to see her. Oh no I
had rather wish to go there and see her.
We write to you very often and I cannot understand
why you do not get the letters. Now do not think
we would forget you because you do not receive our
letters for we write once a week pretty nearly all the
time. [Loll?] one week and I the other. Do not blame
us for not writing often for I think it must be the
Post Masters fault - don't you?
Completed

this is very poor writing but [Loll?] took her gold pen
away with her. excuse the pen if you please. not
the writer. Now I have been such a long long time from
school I shall have to study very hard next winter when
you teach me as I hope and expect you will. I must
get all the sewing done up this Autumn so that I can
have more time for study. Mother says she feels obliged
to you for writing so often for she loves to hear from
you and if you don't write often we shall think
you are sick, we all have to hear from you often and
write you often but it does no good as you do not
get the letters, but for that we shall not stop because
out of five or six you may get one and that will
be something. I am going to write you a letter in French
one of these days. I have it commenced and a good deal
of it written. do you approve of my plan? if it is
not correct you must not be surprised or scold
me any will you? All send much love and
thanks for your good letters. from your sister
Libbie
[Eliz Stedman]
Completed

Tuesday morning April 15
Dear Sister Abby: 
This is a beautiful, bright
spring morning & I feel as though
I should like to get out & enjoy it.
but I find much pleasure as it is
sitting by the window & seeing the
fresh green grass, the trees just putting
forth bud & blossom & the happy little
birds that sing so sweetly to me
every day - there too I have a nice
bouquet of flowers on my stand to
keep me company. O, how pleas-
ant is the spring time!
Are you not anticipating very
much happiness in your new home
in the Country? I mean after the
Completed

moving part is over & you get set-
tled - for I think moving such a
trouble. I thank you for your kind
invitation to me to visit you &
shall accept it as soon as my
health permits. I am anticipating
very much pleasure from the
trip & do so hope I may not
be disappointed about going.
I hope Mr. Kendall will be able
to visit us, for I shall feel so much
safer if I have some one to care
for me when travelling - then too
I think it will do him so much
good to visit his old friends.
Sister is waiting to take this to
the office, so I must close.
With much love your affectionate
Sister Lizzie
Completed

Marietta. Ohio. July 20th 1862
My dear Brother:
Your letter of May 20th now lies
before me, & should have been answered before
this. I've been visiting down in Belpre for
about two months - just got back home Tuesday,
& have got so well & strong I hardly know myself.
When I went down to Belpre I was only able
to sit up a little while every day - now I scarce
ever lie down, & am able to do a "right smart
chance" of work. I do assure you I am very
thankful & happy to be so well again. One
appreciates good health so much after severe
sickness. How is your health by this time?
How does country life agree with you, & your
family also? I dare say the children enjoy it.
I wish you to tell me in your next the name
Completed

of the place where you live, as I do not know -
& the best route I should take to visit you if
I conclude to do so. I think now that I may
visit you as soon as the weather gets cooler -
perhaps by the first of September, but I can't
decide certainly whether I can go or not. My
health is not entirely restored, & I do not think
it best to venture very far from home till
it is, & travelling in such hot weather would
not be of much benefit to me - then, too, I 
have some business matters to attend to that
may prevent my going altogether - so don't
look for me too much as I may be disappointed
after all. Sisters Mary & Charlotte are tolerably 
well this Summer. Sister Augusta still has those
terrible fits & does not get much better. She has
two healthy, bright little girls - one nine & the
other four years old. George does not seem
to be very well contented where he is, wants 
to go West & buy land. I don't know as they will
conclude to go as long as Augusta's health remains
so poor. I think they had better stay as they are
Completed

Sister Abby writes us they are all well. Mr. Greene
is still in Washington & don't know but they'll
all conclude to move there - Sister Abby is trying
to persuade me to make her a visit this summer
instead of you - Oh dear, I wish I could afford
to go both places. William Loring has been
having peculiar kind of fits for the last four
or five years, they are now very severe & frequent
he seems to be losing his mind very much.
Poor fellow, I do pity him very much, he is
so unhappy, & his mother too - it seems as
if she had so many sorrows to bear, but this
seems the hardest of all. Mary & her husband
live in Peoria, Ills. - her health is rather better
than when she was at home. Mr. Putnam's
family are all in good health. Julia & [Haldah?]
are keeping house together in a small house
back on their Father's farm. Their husbands
are both at home for the present. Mr. Cookie is
engaged in Government business - & I don't know
as Mr Wilcox has been doing anything since
he was released - which was some time in 
May I believe.
Completed

It looks so lonely down at the our old house -
there has no one been living in it since
we left, & the trees & everything about it have
grown so much looks as though it needed
some careful hand to trim  up & care for it all.
O, it was so hard to leave my dear old home!
but I've got almost weaned from it now - am
getting used to my new kind of life.
Mrs. Monroe & family are in usual good
health - her Father & Mother are getting pretty
old & feeble. she fears they will not live to
see another spring. Give my love to
Mrs. Kendall & do not forget to answer 
very soon - there are many inquire for
your health & we all feel anxious to hear
how you are. As I do not know your
address I know no better way there to direct 
this to La Porte & trust to having it sent from
there. With much love I remain your
affectionate sister
E. V. Stedman [Lizzie Stedman]
P.S. Where is Lydia this summer?
E. V. S.
Completed

Marietta, Ohio, Oct. 1863
My dear Brother:
I am almost ashamed to write
to you again after waiting so long -
your last letter was written in Jan.
& here it is October - but I assure you
I have thought about it many times
& when it was convenient for me to write
I had not your letter with me & did
not know your address. I have been
in Belpre most of the time this summer
staying with Augusta - I change about
from one place to another & get so unsettled
in mind as well as body sometimes. I
don't feel like writing letters.
George & Augusta sold their place in
Belpre & started from there in August -
Completed

in a spring wagon with their horse to
hunt them a home - where they did
not know - but I guess George thought of
going to Illinois - they got as far as
Woodstock & Augusta had two hard
fits & burst a blood vessel we suppose, for
she commenced spitting up [gnat?] quantities
of blood. George dispatched to me to come
to them & two weeks from the time
I got there, she died - We brought her
to Belpre & buried her by the side of our
other friends. She died the 12th & we did
not get to Belpre till the 17th.
George feels very sad, all broken up as
he is, & says he would go into the
army if it were not for his two
children. I am going to take care
of the children, & I feel that it is not
a small task, for none can do like a 
Mother. George has gone to look for a 
house in Belpre, & if there is none to
be had he will go to Athens I think.
Completed

I have the children here with me at
Sister Charlotte's. Mary is ten years old &
Nina five.
The people in Belpre are about as
usual, there have not been many changes
there since I last wrote - Will Loning
still has his fits & has lost most of
his mind - he is a great care for his
mother. Mary is going to stay with her
mother this winter, her husband is
in Peoria, Ills. 
I suppose you heard of the death of
Mr. Joseph Holden Jr., he fell as
he went to stop from a steamboat
on to a lock, up the Muskingum.
They suppose his head struck against
the stones, for when they took him
out of the water, one side of his head was a
perfect jelly. He lived two days after
they brought him home, but he was 
not conscious any of the time. He
had been doing much better for the
Completed

last year. He died in July.
How is your health now, & that of
your family? I should like very much
to see you all, but do not see that
I can for the present. Have you given
up visiting Marietta & Belpre? I am
sure you have many friends here
that would be very glad to see 
you. Sisters are well & wish to be
remembered to you. Please write
me often & accept much love for
yourself & family from your Sister
E. V. Stedman
[Lizzie]
Completed

[Danford Tyler]
Richmond Dec. 23 1844
Dear Sister
I wrote to mother last week
& informed her that she was Grandmother
& also gave her an invitation to come
over & see her 1st Grand Child. We have
been looking out & expecting to see some one
of you coming every day since I wrote. I
wrote by Wednes's mail. Emily gets along
smart. The Babe is to all appearances healthy
& it has a plenty of that to eat, which it dearly
loves. Emily wants to eat & to work, but
we think she had better be cautious, less she
ventures too soon. Miss Betsy Buffum is
a first best nurse & does up business in good
shape. We have already become attached to
our little one & others say that we have reason
to be proud of it. I hope to see Father
& Mother of here this week if they can come
but if they cannot both come Mother must come
& bring Abby & Mary Ann. I wrote for some [saffron?]
and other herbs but do not [illegible] what now.
Emily wants Mother to come & stay 2 or 3 days now
& longer by & by. Yours &c D Tyler [Danford Tyler]
Completed

Danford 1844

Richmond Aug. 21 1851
Dear Sisters Abby & Mary 
ever sinc our little 
Daughter D came to your special care; You 
will please give your attention to her [diet]. Disentery
is prevalent at this Season of the year, which makes 
it necessary that she should not be allowed 
to eat green Fruit, or [Sauren?] and trust your will 
keep a Motherly eye on her. Her behavior too, we 
hope will receive the Special attention of Miss M., being
a [round?] Graduation of Mr. H. F Seminary, both in their 
domestic circle & abroad. Miss A will please attend to her 
singing & her Sabbath School Lesson &c.
We hope to receive a long visit from you 
this Fall. We will Show you some Striking natural 
Korassities.
Yours &c D. Tyler [Danford] 
I send Janes Geography she reads her lessons out
loud so as to learn to read &c she begins at the 16th 
lessons she can read 5 or 6 lessons & then you ask 
some of the questions & I want her to say some of 
the multiplication every day she could tell it all 
when school was done but she has forgot some & 
I want her to keep it in memory - She keeps begun 
a stocking for Nelly & I want her to knit a lot.
Completed

every day so as to learn to knit fast and well I want 
her to knit the other garter first - she knits 10 rows 
on it forenoon & afternoon you put in some 
needles for I am seeing mine - and when she gets the 
garter done let her finish the stocking & you must 
see about them so as to have them in shape -
I have put in the hair for Nelly and if you get 
time you may fix it for her don't waste it - 
her every day dress & apron need washing - her shim 
and nightcap are damp & have not been ironed - 
if her new drawers are not long enough piece the straps
Emily
don't let her eat but 
3 pieces of cucumbers 
at a time & go to 
bed early
Completed

[n.d.]
Mrs. James Goldsbury tells us the car fare has 
been reduced from $26 to $18 for men and women 
& 1/2 of $18 for children - seems as though you 
could afford to come East yourself this fall & take 
Emma back with you - & perhaps you could 
get her through free.

Richmond Nov. 8 1843
Dear Sister
I am thinking that I should
like to see you & the rest of the Family
I have been very busily engaged at home &
sometime abroad for the past 5 or 6
weeks so that I have formed but a
very little time to visit Friends or
Brothers & Sisters. My own Father & Mother
complain bitterly of my neglect. But I tell
them as I am about to tell you, that
we shall be along that way in the Fall.
my better half anticipates much pleasure
in visiting you, as soon as she can
get ready. Mrs. Allen called on her
yesterday & told her that she had recently
visited at Warwick & I presume told
her many of the long yarn & something
of the Gossip of your villa.
May? when I was at 
at B I could find no fir that was
cut & could buy the skins only by the
doz of the kind you wanted. 
over
Completed

I purchased a Doz of the Cancy skins
& a prime article of the kind, but they
are coloured & I suppose in time will
wear off. I will send a sample of
it if I can enclose it in this letter
& if you would like some of those kind
I will save some & bring it you when
we come over - I will leave room
for Emily to finish. -
Wednesday afternoon
[1843]
Sister Abby
Since Danford has written to Mary
I will write to you so that you can May can both
have a letter in one. I suppose you want me
to tell you all what I am doing &c but less we make
a rape won't we Abby? I will tell you what I am
about & want you & May write me a letter by next
Tuesday & mail & tell me what you are all doing now
you will ? do I say. Mrs. Allen told me yesterday
& that Ann did not want to have the Doct. come to
see her & her uncle L got Mr. Hanstings to persuade
Ann to let the Doct. come to see her; if it is true
I should think that it was rather funny should'nt
you Abby. I want you to tell me all about it
Tell Chandler & Charles that I am real glad that
Completed

they have concluded to teach school this winter I hope
they will succeed well & give good satisfaction tell
them that it is time to be thinking about it so that
they can get their mind all made up to keep a first rate
school. I suppose you will be for trying it next summer
shant you [Drib?]? I suppose the boys are teasing mother
half to pieces to get them ready & you tell them to be-
still ma'am and ma'aming - & come over or let Sam & bring
to me sewing or something they want to have done & I will
do it for them. Now I wish they would for I should like
to help them some if I can, & I had rather not come home
until Thanksgiving week, to stay. & yet have I could not
do a great deal then before they would go to school
you write & tell me what Mother says Oh Abby wont
you going to give us invitation to come home to Thanksgiving
Mother Tyler had, but I guess they will not both come [illegible]
yours is the 30th of this month is it not? I am trying to 
mend up my old red dress! I began it yesterday & I don't get
ahead very [fad?] - it is so ragged. Danford says if I don't
make it look pretty nice I shall find it down in the
rag-barrel! have you got any winter in Warwick today
we have I can tell you - is snowing now. Danford returned week
ago last Friday. I sent a letter to Sarah & he called to see
them. & the Brother David Sarah has told us about went
with him. he says they come right out & say they are
going to be married!! he saw all the folks & they were all
well. He bought me a real pretty muff. it is a grey one
& the prettiest cravat you ever saw when I come home
I shall bring them. He bought some fur but I don't
know as mother will like it to trim Marys cloak with
but I think it is pretty for the kind he could not sell
any other kind here because it would come so high, but
you tell Mary Gimpings are more fashionable than fur
& we have got some real pretty. he says he couldn't find any
fur in strips. Tell Father & Mother I am tired looking out for them
Your affec. sister Emily
Completed

[mostly from Emily]
P.O Richmond January 3 1844                                                                                                                           
Dear Sister
I wish you and all the rest of the 
family a happy New year. The commencement 
of a new year brings with it many pleasant 
associations and I hope that you are enjoying a 
great share of them. I have had little time
to write & shall leave the room to be filled
by my wife. 
Wednesday Afternoon
And Emily wishes you all a happy New 
Year too if I am 10 minutes behind hand.
Dear Sister you wanted me to write you when I 
could get your bonnet done and you may send for 
it Sat. if you would like to for if nothing happens 
I shall have it done. I finished one today for a 
young Lady and others tell me it is a pretty one; it was on 
my new pattern and I shall make yours like this but you 
must not expect a very scrumptious one for the 
silk is quite dirty and faded - I shall make as good a 
one of it as it I can though. I have ripped it to pieces 
this aft. & ironed it and it is a very ill-shaped thing - 
I have starched the old foundation but I don't 
know which I can make in do or not - I don't 
hardly think I can & if I cannot I shall get enough
Completed

for the front part I have made a crown of some
fold pieces I had, & it makes a good one.
Mr. Rawson died last week & I made his robe
I attended his funeral - Mr Livermore of Keene
delivered a discourse - did you ever see how it
does storm. The people celebrated Christmas eve.,
& I had a charming time. The meeting-[Hande?] was
lighted by 2 rows of candles in each window & a
chandelier - & it was beautifully ornamented with
spruces & evergreens - & in the east there was a 
splendid star, as large in circumference as one
of mothers mince-pie plates, to represent the
star of Bethlehem. & we had a good discourse &
some first rate singing too. I wish you could
have heard it. I have not finished my dress
yet not bound my comforter & I don't see as I am
like to. I have made my quilt & got it on, it
is a real good one. I have a [illegible] week now &
I am putting upon it I assure you. Danford is
going to Swanzy tomorrow & we think of going to Father
Tylers Friday. Oh you tell Mother I don't want to
send her cap home quite yet if she can spare it
a little longer I have not had time to make one
yet. I have written to Charles once & we had a 
letter from him yesterday - he says he thinks
he is getting along pretty well; says he has turned
one saucy boy out of school but he came back
& asked to be forgiven & now behaves himself
Completed

says that he attends singing parties & enjoys
himself much better than he did last winter. we
had a paper from Chandler yesterday too. we are
going to write to him to-night. Abby have you &
Mary gained to buy you some aprons yet? if you
have not you must put-right-in for D has got
something that will make you some pretty ones
I have began some silk edging & it will be 
first rate to trim them with I can't stay to write
any more now but I want you & Mary & Sam
to write me a letter won't you?
your affect sister Emily
Does [illegible] take his pepper tea now
every night? how goes the [illegible]
with rover? 
Yours D. Tyler
Completed
