[Emily]
Warwick Apr 6th 1856
Sunday - Maple Grove
My Dear Sister Abby -
I am at mothers today & it
is such dreadful bad going the women can't go to
meeting - you never saw the like of the traveling - it is
fortunate Mary came when she did for she would had
to have come on foot as the rest of the passengers did
she will have a time of it tomorrow - they think of 
carrying her to Winchester & then take the Express to
Brattleboro &c. I suppose you know she had a week after
she got home - I came here Friday Aft. I am going home
tonight. Maria & Samuel are here - Charles seems &
looks better - he has been to Dr. Pierce again - he calls his
disease [crossed out] Larry Glottis
[different handwriting]
Laryngitis (lar-yn-gi-tis) from 'Larynx' I suppose - in the throat -
in Physiology I find 'Larynx' and also 'glottis' - I understood the Dr. to say
Laryngitis although first time he called it a Bronchial difficulty - Charles
[original handwriting]
he gave him medicine that seems to 
help him - you see the name signifies a throat disease
but Charles dreamed he conversed with some learned
person & told him all about it & the person in his dream told
him his disease was Bronchia Chronica, & I believe it
is just exactly the truth of the case, the Dr. says there is 
no consumption about it & his lungs are sound - but that
[written along the top of the page]
I guess better get about 4 yds. trimming for my dress
[written along the left-hand side of the page in the second handwriting]
Abby I just thought I would [too Rolony?] this page - Emily did not quite understand & made a mistake
About the name of the disease
I have looked in Phisiology &
read about Larynx - Laryngitis
and think the section is about right
I think I have been too much
in the habit of viewing it
tight neck, hkf, not being
in a room when there
is a storm, and
also my singing
& trouble &c is all
but for this compounds
I want a cheerful [most?]
and good air
and be careful about
singing with a tight
cravat
Completed

disease may go to his lungs if he don't check its progress
I have got posted up to the time of Mary starting home
& now I want you to write, now she is going off &
spin along the yarn - she thinks she had a capitol
time - & says now she is out of the way you will have full
swing & will probably come home engaged - Samuel &
we have made a little Maple Sugar - Mary says I must
send [Sr.?] a lump - it is ready but don't know as I
can get it to him - I am going to write to him
about it & ask him to send me some coat binding
by you - I had a letter from David last night &c -
Abby Hastings says all Susan's folks have got the measles
So, Pierce has had the small pox & Ann Ward is
very sick now - Mr. Goldsburg's folks have been expos-
ed - Mother has some cold & hoarse & I should not
think strange if she should be sick as she was last
spring before she gets over it. Abby I have taken
the trimming &c of Janes, Marys, and my Bonnets & was going
to have Mary take them to Walpole to be done over
but Mr. Scott is going down in a few days & says
he will take them to you & I have concluded to
Completed

send them by him in care of Abby Lamb - I shall
also send $3 to her care for you to get them
done with & the rest of the things I want you to
get me - I will send directions for the bonnets
with the bonnets - now give 'tikaric' tention - when
you get to Laura's I want you to inquire particu-
larly of them what will be the prettiest for Jane to
wear this summer, for something over her, you know
she has got to have something & you look sharp at
all the little girls & see just what & how made if
they wear silk [bushes? sashes?] I meant you to get a piece of
silk that will be suitable, durable & a pretty color
for her - I think some small plaid or changeable
that would share blue would be prettier than black
ask L & R what they think would be the prettiest
I think something like your dresses would be as cheap
& pretty as anything you could get - I don't want
to pay for $,50 cts per yd & less if you can get good enough for less
- 2 3/4 yds will be enough I guess if
not 3 will certainly - get the trimming - something simple
& to match, to trim sleeves & frill - you can calculate
how much - there will be 3 1/2 or 4 breadths & if flowing
Completed

sleeves calculate for them - get 10 or a doz. buttons but
to match & cheap ones - if Lar Rhoda have got anything
to send up bring it along for they can't because they never
bring anything but a carpet bag - & be sure to ask Laura
how to make the boys velvet jackets - plain, plaited
or gathered - if anything happens that I miss or don't
get a chance to send the money I want you to pay
for Janes fixtures & I will pay you when you get home
I have got an awful cough & raise awful stuff -
D. can't [chop?] 15 minutes without having sort of nervous
or spasmadic teethache he suffers a great deal for a 
long or shorter time - it began to serve him so 5 or 6
weeks ago & grows worse & worse - I don't know as he
will be able to eat - up his woodpile at present -
Mrs. Jillson & little Winnie are dead - & Aunt Lucy
is dead - she had a shock of apoplex Sunday & died
Wednesday Apr 2nd - Mary says perhaps Saphronia
Putnam may be a good hand & you will find her on
Hanover St. No 69. White's Bonnets rooms & perhaps [cansin?]
Abby can refer you to some place where you can get
the bonnets done nice - I wish you would
have the best done with them that can be & look close
& see to them - now you must not think I am going
to put you to too much trouble for you know it will
be a great help to me - & I want you to get me some
trimming that will be pretty & nice enough for my
black silk - I am going to try & get it made -
Mr. Scott don't know certain the day nor that he may start
but just as soon as the going will permit he will
start & if I don't happen to miss shall send a band
box by him containing the bonnets - Mary will put
some things in for you -
Emily
Mary says if you should get trimming like your last for my dress she should want
wider & she says perhaps something like that on your dresses will be pretty
Completed

Warwick Apr 10th 1856
Dear Sister Abby
I come up to Mothers
this morning to get James vaccinated -
there is considerable excitement here about
small pox - Ann Ward died Tuesday &
they are sick at Mr. Connants the millers
& we fear the worst is not over yet - there
has a notice appeared stating that all claims
against Adams &co must be presented
before the 1st of June at San Francisco & he
expects he will be obliged to go to Boston
to see about it - & if he does I shall send by
him instead of Scott - So I will tell about
the Bonnets - I want them all whitened &
pressed - I want Mary's  hat made just the
same that it now is & as large - it won't need
any sewing - Janes I don't want to have any
thing done to it but whitening & pressing if
it can be made into the right shape - if it
Completed

can't, have as little as will do, for I don't
want to have it cost - & mine I want
bleached & pressed & not sewed over it
can be made fashionable without - it may
require a little sewing perhaps - you under-
stand - I want no unnecessary cost - & be sure
to have it made one of the largest sizes
you had better write on a slip of paper
& tack on the inside & tell about it too - see
to them & have them done nice - I want
you to get 1/4 yd white silk for lining some lace
for inside if it is worn & I don't know
whether it is best to put in the old wreaths
or not, but if ribbon is worn the most get
some & that which is suitable - but perhaps
you need'nt get the inside ribbon & I will
scratch up something here - but get lining &
lace if it is worn - & get the outside trimming
I think I like white ribbon the best for
summer - better than colored - get some that
Completed

is pretty, & will wear well, & as cheap as you
can - if you get a lining for yourself you can
get 1/2 yd & cut it right through from corner to
corner & it will be better shape for both of us
- I want Jane's made the summer still & I thought
it was so thin it might be without sewing
over - you know Mary said it cost ,25 cents for whiten-
ing & pressing & she had hers sewed a little &
altered so as to press in still & cost ,37 1/2 & that was
done at Boston she says - Mother talks of send-
ing hers but not certainly concluded - if she
does she says you must see to it & have it
done nice or she shant touch it! she says she
don't want it made small - you must look &
see just how to trim mine & Janes - if it
comes right get Rhoda to rine & trim mine - & I
wish they would one of them send me one
of their bonnets they are done wearing for a 
run-about-bonnet - I guess by this time you will
say I have said enough about the bonnets &
now I better talk about something else
Completed

Mary went to Walpole & took a miniature &
we sent a letter to Stoughton Tuesday & particularly
& this is the business letter - I concluded to
send you $4, instead of $3, & enclose $4, & you
must send me word right off whether you can get
& if there is any point you don't understand
write up & I can write back & explain - I want
you to get something for Jane a bask & the trimmings if they are
fashionable just as I wrote you in the Stoughton
letter - I think some pretty plaid or changeable like
your dress that shades blue will be pretty - but you must look round
& get a good bargain - must'nt pay over 50 cts per
yd. - & I sent in my other letter to have you get
some trimming for my black silk -if Maire Antique
is most fashionable get that, but wider than that on
your bask - perhaps something like that on your silk dresses
may be more fashionable & pretty - I don't think
best to have anything costly or extravagent
but nice & good enough to pass muster -
Mary said she thought it would take 4 yds
you must make my $4, go a good ways for it is
my all & I borrowed $1, into the bargain - you
must not let any body see this letter - I don't
know but black may be more fashionable for Jane
but I thought it would cost more, see what L &
Rhoda say - 2 3/4 or 3 yds will be enough, & I rather
think 2 3/4 will answer - you must write often so
that we can know your whereabouts - snow is
beginning to disappear - Mary said she could not get
at your [milts?] & sends shawl, [bisilte?], ribbon & wreaths
Emily
Completed

Warwick June 22nd 1857
Dear Sister Abby
We have received your fat
letter & it has been passed all round in the family
circle, & soon to start on a visit to Charley - as
you supposed Mother had lost many a night's
sleep on your account, because she knew something
had happened, & we all began to think strange
we had no intelligence from you - you said when you
wrote in Albany you would write again soon you
know - we all feel quite relieved to know you
have arrived safely, & happy too, to know you are
enjoying yourself so well - but I'll not stop to
comment for I have only a moment that I can
write I am [expecting?] Mother to call every
moment & I am going to Athol with her -
Mary said I must write the news from my
part of the town so I'll tell you of Maria's & Samuel's
new baby! it is a little girl! & looks just as
Ally did precisely - it seems like Ally right over
again - they have not named her yet. -
[written on the left-hand side of the page]
they are talking of having a pic nic on the 4 of July - and going to celebrate
in the adjoining town - our school will close next week Friday - Jane
likes Algebra & is
progressing finely
Completed

I had to officiate as midwife - I went for Mrs.
Williams but the babe was born 1/2 hours before she arrived
& S & I, self were alone with Maria & therefore obliged
to act - I went over at 11 in the evening & the babe
was born at 1/2 past 12 only 1 1/2 hours! & very
comfortable - she is all about & is going home this
week - you need'nt read the particulars to Mr.
Kendall if you think it will dash his modesty -
I wrote a few thinking you would like to know -
Mary & I assisted her 3 days then Susan 4 & now Martha Lawrance
Samuel's blind horse has a nobby looks like Milly's
cold - now look out beside the road - where the
appletree grove is, & see if you cannot see it!
Mr. Tim Tabins & wife have parted he has
gone off with Mrs. French - didn't you anticipate
it? Mrs. Barnard Fisher is numbered with
the dead - she died very [suddenly?] in a few days
after you left town - an abscess in the lower
part of the abdomen was the cause of her death
when it broke she died - it discharged inwardly & outwardly
My children are at school & don't know I am
writing or they would have messages to send - D
is well & send best respects to you & yours remember me to
my brother! your sis Emily
[written along the left-hand side of the page]
you must write regular & often you remember the agreement don't you?
Completed

Warwick Feb 28th 1858
My dear Sister Abby
I have not forgotten your claim to
an ans. to your last letter but you was so wicked to
neglect writing so long to your Sister Emily she had almost
a mind to make you wait & wonder "why she don't write" as
long as I did - & now you see I am returning good for evil
you know Abby full well how few spare moments are
mine v. how little leisure time I can call my own to
devote to reading or writing & so have not written as much
as usual of late, but you cannot have any good reason
for neglecting to write me 6 or 7 months, & I am sure I could
not understand the long delay & now surely for the future I
shall take as much time to ans. your letters as you take to
write them - Danford is writing this evening & my desire to
keep him company prompted me to thus easly ans. your last.
We have been to meeting to day as usual & heard the
Rev. Mr. Tenny discourse - & all readily admitted his two
sermons today were the best & ablest he ever delivered in our
church - & they were not of the common place I assure you
We are not to have a minister for a few Sabbaths
as the money subscribed has been used up & Mr Goldsburg
wishes to make his annual visit to his children & will
start for Boston this week - but it is proposed to have the
house kept open & it seems to be the mind of all that it
will be better to have "Deacon-meetings" than go to the alters
There has been quite a revival among the orthodox
this winter & many "entertain a hope" the converts are
mostly of the young people - by the way I hear the Deacons
Completed

Ellen is to be married to a brother of Mr. Bridge
Bently Sangers came out with his wife today - he was married
to Martha Allen a week or two since - they took a seat with
Mrs. Gale & Martha's face was as red as a beet - this new
couple makes the 4th that were present today - W. R. Bell, Mr.
Farnsworth, & Chandler - I wish you could have been here today
you would have enjoyed it so well I know & we would have
enjoyed so well to have seen you in your old seat among
the choir & heard you sing - but now I must stop right here
or I'll be saying it is to much of a sacrifice to have you
live so far from us -
Harriette Draper visited me last
Tuesday & told me she should be married in about 3
weeks from that time - She will go to Chicago to live & is
going to keep house so I am thinking you will improve
the first opportunity to see her & have a long talk over
I have always felt that Hattie was to good for Mr. Atwood
but as I am not so well acquainted with him cannot so
well appreciate his worth - most of all I don't like to have
take her so far from us for she is one of our best young
ladies & very dear to me & I shall miss her so much. her
family will dread the how far separation & Mrs. Draper & Mary
can hardly feel reconciled at the thought of it - & I'm thinking
it will be hard for Hattie to live so far from them she loves
her home so well - I conclude they will be married & leave
town in the P.M. from what she told me & in as quiet
a manner as possible, you know that is Hattie's way
Hannah Hastings, William's wife is dead. She died of
consumption of the blood - was very much like Zebiah -
Hannah left 3 children to mourn the loss of a mother &
William refuseth to be comforted - his temperament is
[written along the left-hand side of the page]
Mary and Charlie send much love to you and Mr. Kendall. Mary is going to write you soon.
write oftener
Completed

such his affliction nearly makes him insane - or has
an effect upon his mind similar to that made at the
time he was disappointed by a lady in Brattleboro - you'll
recollect the circumstances I'm thinking -
It is my birthday tomorrow & town meeting day too
& we are all going to spend the day at mothers - I believe
they are not anticipating so pleasant & agreeable results
as the last tow meeting - the other party will have
the ascending it is feared - Maria & her children are
going up too - Mrs. E Stevens will spend the day with
Rhoda - D. has served his time & got up a good
report quite surpassing the last year's, we think
of course, & now a new board of committee will be
elected, if the other party have the power -
We are invited to Frank [Major's? Maye's? Meyer's?] Wednesday &
Mr. & Mrs. Green also - Mariah Stevens & her mother
have come back to live on their old place again &
a few talk of giving them a welcome in the shape
of a surprise -
Samuel & his wife & children, Chandler & his
wife, Charles & Mary & Jane visited at Uncle Marks
last week - they had a nice time - we would liked to
have gone but D. was busy making out the school report
& I thought I would not enjoy to go without him so we
shall go another time - it is pleasanter visiting
there now they have moved from the old house - they
have pleasant rooms now &c.
Mrs. Young & her 3 daughters visited here last Thursday
we had a happy time - they came in the morning &
staid all day - she told me a great deal about
England that was very interesting - she tells me Miss
[written along the left-hand side of the page]
Mother says you must not forget to send her confidential note
Completed

cook is regaining her former health since she
returned to her native land - I wonder if she sings
God Serve the Queen now without shedding tears
March 1st My 37th birthday is here & I am enjoying
it a sight & would you like to know the result of
Town meeting? well Mr. Draper resigned his Town Clerkship
knowing he was to have been removed if he did'nt because
he joined with those who wished Mr. Morgan to be the P.M.
& Henry Mallard was chosen. The same board of
selectmen as last year - for committee Mr. Bridge
Dr. Hill & Charley Gale - Mr. Goldsburg Treasurer &c
I suppose this is all you care to know of it -
I am seated in Mothers little kitchen writing you
Mary & Mother have moved in the old desk & it is
[wise? mine?] to write on - Mothers health is quite good for her
but Charles is very much that spring he was here before
he went to B- he still keeps the best foot forward & tries
so hard to feel well as he used to -
We have an interesting Lyceum I have attended them
all - we have a lecture once in 2 weeks & the week
there is no lecture an original paper Edited by 6
young Ladies is read in its place - our Sister Mary is
at the head of the list - & I wish you could read some
of her washtub bubbles as she calls them - Jane has contri-
buted one piece since our school closed - Sarah is with
us yet but don't expect she will be but a few weeks longer
we are getting tired of her - Charles has just come home
from the town meeting & presented me with an orange
because it is my birthday he said & one for Allie for
her birthday - Samuel & Maria have gone home so as to get
home before dark. the snow is almost gone & we shall begin
the sugaring right away - a great many good wishes for your
husband - the children are sending so much love I don't know where
to put it - Emily
Completed

[Emily]
[Partly copied]
Warwick May 30 1858
My Dear Sister Abby
This day so reminds me
of your wedding day that I must talk a little with
my pen - I am aware last Sabbath was the 
anniversary but today is warm & cloudless so pleasant.
I am thinking it would do you good to take a peep into
Maple Grove - also along Elm Street - Every thing is
looking more forward than a year ago but we have
been having a fortnight rain & cast winds & today is
the first really pleasant Sunday like the day you & Mr
Kendall joined hands as well as hearts -
Last Sabbath we all stopped to Mothers & all suppd
the same as we did a year ago & talked over Abby's
Birthday & wedding day &c &c, & we would have enjoyed it
still more could you & yours have been with us too
Sister Laura & her children were at Rhoda's & she
sang all day - her voice was a rich as ever & it
was a treat I assure you - she refused to sing & did'nt
the first sabbath but so much was said they prevailed
upon her to sing last Sabbath - Frank didn't happen
to be there but Wallace & his melodeon was & we
had some excellent singing - Our folks thought Mr.
Goldsburg enjoyed it too for they said he selected the longest
Hymns - & now Abby let me remind you that you can
& ought to retain your voice & sing as well as Laura
& Rhoda, beside I don't think it right to bury a talent
that God has given you & I know you will regret it
sometime if you do and be obliged to confine your
Completed

singing to [Hebron & board?] as I do
Laura has a little Rhoda Mabelle about 6 months
old - it is one of the prettiest, & so good too - I think it is
a sight of comfort to her & helps to heal the wound the
death of her little Ida gave her - David came up
& they all returned yesterday - he is getting rich - he told
Danford that he had made $1000, in a single day but
he don't allow these things to be talked about so you must
not you know. he is looking very healthy & Laura's health
is much better than it was when she was here
last - They are very anxious to have Jane go to Waltham
this fall but we think it will do her more good when
she is a little older - we expect the rest of them to
visit us this season. Byron is a little man - Eva is
pretty but is very much afflicted with the [St. Vita's dence?]
Laura said we must tell you that you need'nt
borrow at trouble about your approaching sickness for it
is called a good year, & every body gets along nicely - you
know she is posted about these things - & she says it
is said so by all the Physicians & has proved so thus
far, & I know it has been so in this vicinity, so you
may take courage, all the courage in the world - &
just think of Mrs. Davis she was 42 besides a
feeble woman & Patience has another little girl &
had a very comfortable sickness compared with what
she ever has had - William says they go for girls
"because they are less liable to be sent to states
prison or [huny?]" but we think he would be willing to
run the risk if he could have had a son
Laura says almost every one goes more than their
time before confinement this year perhaps it may be so
[written along the left-hand side of the page]
Chandler & Rhoda seem to enjoy themselves "beyond account"
they are nicely mated & very much alike & think everything of each other
Completed

with you too - she said she waited a whole month nearly
lost all patience in waiting - I wish you were here
so I could talk with you there is so much I would
like to say to you & it is no use in attempting to write all
I would like to say for it would take me a week -
June 2nd - I intended to have finished my
letter at the time I commenced it but it got late &
thought I could finish in the morning but here it is
[rock?] P.M. Wednes P.M. & I am bound to finish it this time & if you
get some hastily written words never mind it -
well would'nt you like to know what I have been doing
today? after I got the children started for school my work
got done up in a hurry & I then took the fire shovel &
commenced setting out Dahlias, Gladiolas, China asters &c
it has been a real warm summers day & I was tired
I assure you. I didn't get through till Mary came from
school - Mary is boarding at Samuel's but she stops every
night & morning & I enjoy it a sight - Maria & the
children have been here most of the afternoon - she
is weaning little Abby so takes her over here to amuse
her - Samuel has made Maria a border in front of
house & I went over & set out 4 Dahlias for her
Now tell me if you work in the garden among the
flowers or are you more comfortable to keep yourself quiet
I wish you would tell me all you know I can be as
secret as you wish, & I shall feel much better to know
exactly the state of your health - you say you have engaged
a nurse & I hope she is an experienced one - Betsy
Buffum-like - but more than all take good care for yourself -
keep yourself as calm & quiet as possible after your delivery
for very much will depend upon it afterwards - I mean
[written along the left-hand side of the page]
Charles worked for D. yesterday so Mary stopped to take supper with us too
C. is very much changed from what he was - he is pleasant & happy & seems
to enjoy himself - I think his troubles were quite too much for him at
time he first met them - I have not seem him look so well 
since he came from California as now
Completed

your mind & nervous system for you will gain strength
very much faster - don't let undue care or anxiety for
the little one disturb you in the least - till you begin to feel
like yourself again - I can look back to the birth of my first born & see how I
mistook the natural order of things - feel that I can advise - Oh
there is so much I want to day to go I may as well stay now as any
way - Mrs. Lawrence was buried today she died of consumption
Dea. Barber attended the funeral - they are Spiritualist -
Abby May is to be married next Wednes. at 7 o'clock A.M.
at the Unitarian House - we shall have to take an early start
if we go I'm thinking - she called here yesterday with Louis
& gave us an invitation - Mary thinks they will have considerable
parade - you know Abby enjoys it - Mary Draper commenced school
in Flower Hall district & was obliged to leave last week on account
of her ill health - Miss [Manille Albee?] commenced down
on [Santh?] Dis. & could'nt manage them & left - Fannie Delvy
had the same luck in No. G. - Mary & Anne [Mayo? Marge?] seem to 
be the stay of the town - Miss Libby is teaching on the Brook & Miss
Litchfield is No. 1 & they are likely to succeed -
Mary says she wants Mr. Kendall to present you the
Ticket he purchased for her & to come home when Sarah
& your sister comes east in company with her - we have
got our hearts set upon it & I think you will be smart
enough & we shall be so impatient to see the little "Bud"
you must not disappoint us - & make arrangements with
Lydia to keep house for you & Mr. Kendall to come for
you if he could'nt leave his business to come & make a long
visit with you - we want to get more acquainted with him & it
is quite time - Mother told me lots & lots to tell you & O
dear! I can't this time - she has got a yard full of chickens
& turkeys & they keep her busy as ever
much love for yourself & Mr Kendall good bye 
Sis Emily
[written along the left-hand side of the page]
Jane says she is going to ans. Aunt Abby's pretty note & sends love - Danford &
the boys are up to the other place at work - Mary Abby is gone to stay 1/2 hour to "Allies house"

Warwick Feb 27th 1859
Dear Sister Abby
I have got seated to ans.
your letter & Mary says she left it at home
& perhaps I'll not be able to ans. it fully
but I will do what I can towards it - Mary
is beside me writing two & if you get
two letters written alike 'twould'nt be strange
We have ate our good Sunday supper &
the children are now in bed all but Jane
& would you like to know what we had for
supper? well we had roast, not baked,
sparerib & potato & gravy, brown bread & butter
warmed up boiled corn & maple molasses &
nutcakes - we were indebted to Mary for
the boiled corn, she got it up to Rhoda's &
was going to make her supper of it but as
she staid here she divided with us & it was
"super excellent" - I think you might eat it if 
boiled very tender & the alkali in it agree with
your stomach - we are all very well now
[written along the left-hand side of the page]
The sign comed right - the 24 & 25 of March - that is Thighs Thighs
Completed

except Danford - he & Chandler were both
badly hurt a week ago yesterday (the 20th) by a
tree falling upon them - they were chopping pines
on Mr. James Goldsburg's land between L. Gold-
sburg's & Mr. Pierce's eight land side going to
town - they had just cut 3 trees & stopped to 
see them fall & that was the last they knew
until they came to again & found themselves
under the tree & in the brush of it - it
appears that as they were standing looking at
the falling of those they had cut, another that
had been cut some time before & lodged on
a maple came unexpectedly & in another
direction & struck them down instantly &
senseless to neither knew how or what hurt
them & probably never would if they had happened
to have been killed or their reason had been
impaired - they were both struck on the
head & crashed down & hurt very much
alike -- C hasn't held his head natural till

to day - he complains most of his neck 

& D of pain right through from the chest to 
the back - I have kept a fire every night
[written along the left-hand side of the page]
don't attempt to wean Eddie without a bottle you can get used to
it a little before you commence weaning him
Completed

for he is in severe pain if he is in any
position long at a time & it is difficult to
move then at all - Abby this was an almost
miraculous escape - we think it over & wonder
how it could have been done & they not instantly
killed - they have both been great sufferers from
pain but I think C is going to get better first
if nothing new takes hold of him - he has a
stronger constitution than D you know -
they are feeling more comfortable now but
can't do anything yet - C thinks he could
work some if the could only move his head
he thinks he shall be well enough to begin
again a little at work before the week is
out - D don't sit up half of the time yet but
sort of comfortable now so though he reads all he
can get hold of - but I expect it will be a 
long time before either will outgrow it & feel
free from the effects of it - but I feel so 
thankful they are alive I'll not complain -
I have got a bed moved into our dining 
room & the Secretary moved out so he changes
from the bed to the lounge quite often
[written along the left-hand side of the page]
here's lots of love for Charlie, but in close quarters - D is going to
write to him soon & then I'll write a line - you must'nt forget
to have him take good care of his health
Completed

Rhoda has been to Waltham on a visit &
happened to get back the Thursday before he
got hurt we think it was very fortunate
for he needed a great deal done for him
& Mother could'nt have done it for him
for she does well if she can manage to
take care of herself - Now Abby I want
you to do just what I told you too for your
self - for I know it is what you need you
must'nt go without eat but be judicial
in what you eat - you need the most
nourishing food that is the easiest of di-
grestion & I know & mean what I said about
eatables when I wrote you last be sure to make
use of the poultice I told you about for the
piles let it be either kind & the other
remedies I found very beneficial in my 
own case a few years ago you will
remember my affliction I guess - don't you
know I used to suffer as though they were
travair pains - & one thing more, when
you have anything pass & these little 
bunches or tumors pass out too, before
Completed

you rise from the stool put your hand
outside your chemise & press with your
fingers gently upon them & make them
go back to their natural place again. &
you'll not suffer so much pain afterwards
about weaning Eddie. Mary will fin
out the time when in the Almanac & tuck it in some-
where but if she dont, [sic.] get Thomas
Almanac & look at the signs where it
says head, head, -- belly, belly -- &c & where

& that'll be the time -- you must take my
advice in this matter & when I see you I
can give all explanations -- The pills
( the blue pills,  I guess have calomer [sic.] in them
that you mentioned -- but it wont ans.
for me to interfere with the  Doct[or] doing...
I suppose as any of his prescription -- 
& mar your "growing". I mistrust but of

I [sic] mistrust may be caused by natures

time of of your confinement -- If I recollect
right of what was written about that time
you were of necessity obliged to keep
very still & consequently all that ought
to pass of at that time perhaps did'nt
hence an attempt on the part of nature
by growing to be freed from any refuse in the form of clotted blood
that might not belong in or about the

but it may not have been the case

Warwick, May 2nd, 1871
[from Emily]
My dear sister,
Did you receive my letter
dated Apr. 27th asking for an ans. by Monday's
mail? Also, if you would meet me at Greenfield
May 1st? Well, I hired Everett to go up for the
mail Monday, & no letter? - My condition
then, was, that I should see you at Green-
field the next day without fail, so went
myself [allasdingly?] - But I did not find
you there, consequently, was unprepared
to do anything except get what inform-
ation I could upon the subject under
consideration - I do not understand
why you neither ans'd my letter, or joined
me at Greenfield? 
I examined the Records & found a 
warranty deed of our old homestead, from
Henry Barber of Warwick - Chas. Gale of Philadelphia,
& Jasper Gale of Framingham, to, Mary A Osgood
[written along the left-hand side of the page]
There now, I have tried to give you precisely & impartially the facts as I see 
them transpiring & it is all I can do without your cooperation &
approval - I have tried
to do my duty towards
our sister & all by tell-
ing these things to you
that have come to
my knowledge
If Sam'l & Dea. B. persist
in carrying out what they 
have commenced after 
knowing we object, we
ought to acquaint the
judge of the facts at
once, & previous to
next [years? times?]. the day they
have set for making the
application - now do not
be unmindful of this
fact - we ought to do
at once what is done as
I think as the matter
will pass entirely 
by and our reach [farewell?]
Please ans. immediately 
& in full, that I may know
what & how you will do -
Completed

Marlboro, N.H. - dated, Dec. 3d - 1870 - Recorded
in Book 293, Page 156 - delivered to H. Barber.
At the time of Mary's last visit here, she
took the deed, I think, but not without an effort
on the part of Sam'l to put her off, as she told
me at that time. I suppose Mr. Osgood has it now.
I managed to see Judge Conast & tell him 
rather briefly about the case, & I'll tell you as
nearly as I can what he said.
He said he could not tell for certain
until he saw all the papers whether or not it
would be rendered real estate or personal property?
If Real Estate her brothers & sisters were her
legal heirs - that the moment her breath left
her body her property became her heirs, for
there was no time that any property could be
without ownership? Therefore, the heirs could
take what was theirs. In other words, col-
lect themselves what belonged to them & no
Administration was necessary. Because,
as there were no debts to settle, & no personal
property to dispose of during Mr. Osgoods
[written along the left-hand side of the page]
I asked Judge Conast who by right was legally entitled to Adm'r where
where brothers and sisters were the lawful heirs & he said any one of the brothers or
sisters
might Adm'r or the
preference
usually
being given
to the
eldest - 
or, the eldest
male heir,
next -
I understand
Judge C-
to say that
if agreed
we could
settle the
whole matter
among our-
selves - 
but here
is the

a lifetime, there was nothing to be administered

Sam'l says he holds a writing obligation from

Judge Conast says, this writing lying back
of the warranty deed, may convert it into
a mortgage, & if so, this note property

& farthermore, that securities were often

But if personal, I do not see how (by

Evidently, this question, ether or not

must be decided before anything can be done.
But, Sam'l told me he had given all his

She talked with me about them, then; &
again, when I was at Granby, the June pre-
vious to her death.
Mary never intended to give Sam'l
her money to pay for the place, but loan
it to him till he could have a little more time

Warwick Aug. 25th 1872
Dear Sister Mary -
I have just returned 
from church & I'll just write you a few 
words but I must do it hastily as usual.  
Henry Barber preached today & his 
discourses were very excellent. I can see 
decided improvement in both his style 
and manner, also the sermons - Oh how 
well he has succeeded - well, he has 
ever been a willing master in his 
calling - there are many in town yet, 
from abroad, but not as many as 
last year - H.H. Jillson and Nettie Bell 
were married Aug. 21st - are making 
a short trip among the N.H. hills - 
I haven't heard a word from 
Abby or her family since you were 
here - perhaps it is because her 
good letter still remains unans'd.
Completed

I wish she would not mind it or be
to particular, for I have so many letters
to write, & so much to do, & think about 
I can't do as I ought in the matter of 
letter-writing - 
Samuel's folks are quite well, & Sam'l
seems more cheerful & chipper than a
while ago -
Aunt Reed has been dangerously
ill - Erysipelus to commence her
sickness, & then Dysentary - John came
up & has been with her a week -
Malinda went up 2 weeks ago today
& came home today for the 1st time -
she will go back tomorrow -
Well, I may broach the subject
that weighs most heavily just at this 
time, as well first, as last!
Jennie has sent for Mary to
go to Europe to do some of her
studying, & for me to accompany
her & I have decided to go!!!!
I expect Mary home tomorrow -
we will have to be on our way in
Completed

about 2 weeks! thus you see how
much there will be for me to do -
I wish you could be nearer to lend a
helping hand just at this pinch - I really
wish I could see you again before I am
off - can't you come & pass a week, or
two with me before I go?
I may not get started this time,
but expect to - everything is in better
condition for for me to go away for a 
season now, than when I started
before - & for some reason I have
not the least dread of attempting
the journey - I suppose my ignorance
of its fatigue & dangers may be the reason
of it - but there is one prayer, & one
hope crowning all others - & it is this -
that all our lives, & health may be preser-
ved, & that I may be permitted to
return safe & well - & at the last
my body repose in its grave beside
my dear Danford's - has it occurred
to you that the 2nd anniversary days of
his sickness & death were over & gone? & now are
as the things that belong to the "Eternal past"?
Completed

but of these two long, lonely years without Danford, none
can know all - I think it will seem unpleasant & sadening
to me if I cross the Atlantic, most of all, if the children I leave
behind should be sick or unfortunate - Mary you must keep
yourself well posted in regard to them, & report minutely
to me - & next, to be so far from the grass of my husband
seems very trying to think about -
Now Mary will you write to my dear Sister Abbie
& Brother Charles & inform them of my purpose to go
to visit with Jennie - but I shall leave much love behind
for you all - Jennie is troubling & we expect to join
them at Havre, or at some other French of German port - 
I will try to write you again when I know certain the 
time we shall start unless you should come to see me
off & pull the string in - Flora Bassett is here - she expects
her father & mother to come for her this week
much love to you
all - your affect. Sister
Emily
Completed

Granby, Conn. Sept. 23d 1873
Dear Sister Abbie
I am glad to address
you, feeling that I am so near home -
I arrived here the 11th & expect to
start for my home in Warwick tomorrow
I rather dread the work of putting things
in working order; I left Mary, Emilie
& her husband at Balse, Switzerland, &
returned alone; they will continue
their journeyings longer, going to Vienna
&c - I have enjoyed my year of travel
exceedingly, & shall have much food for
thought when alone - James & Reed are
in Boston at school - I do not expect to
remain at my home this winter, but have
not decided yet where I had best make my
winter quarters - I shall be at Warwick
probably till Nov. & if you come East, come
& make me a visit. I have thought of you
a great deal the past few days - I knew
what & where your thoughts would be - Mary
was writing & I thought I would write
a line but they are ready now to go to P.O.
& I must close by saying I hope to see you
soon - much love for you & your children - 
[written along the left-hand side of the page]
Please write me soon, your Affec. Sister Emilie
Completed

Warwick Apr. 11th 1875
Dear sister Abby,
As I commence
this to you, the thought comes,
that there is no longer any "dear
Sister Mary" we can ever again
address - you cannot imagine
how unreal & sad & strange the
thought seems to me - & must
it be that we never more can
see her again, or hear her voice,
or receive her precious messages?
but it is even so -
It is too bad - & ever day I 
feel more & more that she
has been sacrificed - How I
wish I could have a little talk
with you tonight, instead of writing?
I want to say some things confi-
dentially, & will you promise not
to tell Chandler of this I write, or
any one, & burn this letter as soon
as you have read i? Now Abby
you must do this as I desire -
not reveal what I write, & destroy it.
Completed

Well, Mr. Osgood came here &
took dinner with us the day you
& Chandler went home - As you
know, we were expecting he would
go with you, & I was a little sur-
prised to know he did not go with 
you - he went back to Samuel's direct-
ly after dinner - I managed to 
bring up about Mr. & Mrs. Jones
calling &c & he being away - & don't
you think he mentioned calling at
Dea. Barbers, & Mr. Spooners, but in
no way alluded to his call at
Mrs. Libby's! So I said nothing - 
but I have heard that Mrs. Libby
was at Samuel's in the evening!
& if so, you were there, & know all
about it - & the next day, Mr. O-
and Maria visited at Mr. Weston's! &
I presume Mrs. L- was invited there, 
but do not know quite certain
about it - today, he went into the
pulpit & preached just as if nothin-
ing had happened - when he
came down from the pulpit after
the services, Mrs. S- was all
fixed, & the 1st to greet him -
& as you may know everybody
looked & looked -
Completed

Abby, I may be mistaken, &
misjudge him, but to judge from
appearances, I never in all 
my life saw such manifest
heartlessness - I have not the
least doubt, he offered to sup-
ply today, & do you not know
how he go excused from
his society, so as to be quiet
& rest - It seems as though he
only preached for the effect
it might produce, on certain
ladies - I did not want to hear
him, but people might make
remarks if I staid at home -
but his preaching would never
do me any good -
One word about Mary's prop-
erty - the more I think of it, 
the more it seems stupid in
her brothers & sisters to allow Mr.
O- & Maria to have all the
managing of our mothers &
sisters things, & affairs - I know
Mary would rather an own
sister should attend to her affairs
now she is gone - Mr. O & his
family have had the good of
them 5 1/2 years, & he ought to con-
sider it so
Completed

& now Mary is gone, return them
to the rightful heirs - her brothers
& sisters - but there must be
an administrator to administer
upon her property, or it cannot
be legal or satisfactory, & if it
is my right, or any of the brothers
or sisters right, it is their duty
to attend to it at once - if we
allow our privilege to [slide by?]
Mr. O will certainly do it, & 
all in his own way you may
depend - & after telling us we could
have something of our sister's that
we could take home in our 
pocket, it is pretty evident
how things would be managed
under his administration -
He will have another wife in less
than 6 months if he can get one, & 
who of us want Mary's & Mother's things
at their disposal - & I do not believe
he cares one straw for anything, any
farther than it can be changed into
dollars & cents to put into his pockets
& as far as his girls they have all
their mothers things, & in a way
to earn more as well as any of us - of
course I would have them have
some keepsake for I verily believe
they would prize it more than
their father would - Mr. O said
he should go to the Hudson tomorrow
& he may say something to you & C.
but he had not mentioned the subject
to me since the 1st time
Completed

I enclose a small lock of
Mary's hair so you can use
it for the purpose you
mentioned if you wish -
Monday Morn. at the P.O.
I came up & brought Mary so
as to go with Mr. O. to the depot
Samuel was going to take them
down - I asked him if he would
stop long in Hudson & he said
probably not - I asked if he would
go to your house or Chandlers? &
he said Chandlers! & farther
said he did not know as he
should go to see you as you had
not invited him too, & he should
not go without an invitation!
& added he thought very strange
of it after you had stayed
so long at his house in Marlboro
I told him you were expect-
ing him & he ought not to
think of any such thing - but
they were all ready to start &
I could not say anymore - Now
you must not let him know I
have told you of this, but I thought
you ought to know of it - with love good bye
Completed

Have you or C had any talk will
William Bassett or any one else?
& if so, what do you learn in regard
to the legality of the thing to be done.
I tell you Abby, with Mr. O & 
Maria, it has seemed more like
a season of rejoicing than of mourn-
ing, even since the first day of
Mary's death; & I am disgusted
with some things I have seen &
heard -
Now I have expressed myself
freely to you & I wish you would
do the same, but all this I write
in confidence you must keep
& not expose -
Did you reach home safely & 
find your families all well?
Have you got rested? I am sure
I am not rested yet -
Jonas went to Keene yesterday &
Mary goes to New Salem tomorrow
morning -
I cannot see how Sister Mary's property
can be settled satisfactorily & final
without being done legally - I am
very tired & sleepy & must say
good night to you - Please write
very often - your affec. sister - 
give my love to the children
Completed

Warwick, May 21 1875
My dear & only sister
The busy spring-
time with its never-ending demands upon
my time has prevented me ans' your 1st
letter, but I'll take the time right out of
"whole cloth" now, lest days & weeks will
glide away, leaving the 2nd unanswered too. 
I am glad those people of Mr.
Osgood's society have put their shoulder
to the wheel, striving to make the good
work move on, that one angel sister
loved so well, & devotedly -
Oh Abby, Mary is dead & gone - It does
seem some days when I am thinking
a great deal about our loss of so dear
a sister, as though I should cry my eyes
out - If I could only see you such
times, & talk over about her, perhaps I
should not feel so grieved - It has
seemed [as?] the time from 1st as though it
could not be, & as time goes on I grow less rec-
onsiled to her early death I fear! It seems
a dreadful loss to me, to lose her &
give her up entirely: I wonder if it does
seem so great a bereavement to you &
our brothers? there are other things I ought
to write you, so I must not write it all
about poor Mary -
I feel so sure about Mr. Osgoods doings 
& sayings I don't care to mention him -
[illegible] what you wrote me concer-
ning his remarks about me? Well he may
talk on till doomsday if he likes I
have not "misused" him or said any
[written along the left-hand side of the page]
I shall be so very glad to see our long absent brother Charles? I hope he will
be well so he can enjoy his visit - I do not see any way that I can help with
money - I have sold only 1 ton of hay - $20, & this I have had to use nearly
all of it to pay
Jona; for
money our [rough?]
when I went 
to Granby, & for
eatables -
I would help
of course if I
had anything
to help with
you &
Chandler &
Samuel,
have some-
thing "coming
in" & I have
nothing, but all
"gain out" -
I have been
to Athol today
for Mary - she
returns next
Monday - she 
calls herself well
but complains of
feeling tired -
Completed

improper thing to him - I told you
all I did say at the time; & if it is
anything I said in regard to mothers things that
he means, I only spoke the truth, & I'll
say the same again if he gives me the
opportunity! he broached the subject
& I said just as little as possible, but
he knows that justice would give them
back to us, if the law does not - It seems
to me that his object was to get up some
matter of offence against us, for an
excuse to withhold Mary's & Mother's
things! So told me that stuff about
you & then goes to you, & tell a mess
to you against me - If I had said or
done anything wrong, why did not he speak

I have not & he knows so too - & he will
have to tell me what I am to apologize
for, or go without any, for I am sure I
cannot conceive what it can be -
I do not care a straw, either -
did he tell you of the spiritual meeting
at Samuel's the next night after you left?
they got a medium from Vt. & had a great
performance with an instrument - All
kept secret from me but several [illegible]
It has been a "towns-talk" & poor [Susan?]
Childs came near having her head
seriously injured by a [illegible] from the
instrument - It struck her in her fall
& hurt her dreadfully & the bruise was very
black & blue - I have heard that there
has been other meetings of some sort
since - I am sorry, sorry - It will be
bad for Samuel, certain sure -
I have read a letter from Carrie which
said little May & Abby were improving
in health - It was written soon after Mr.
O's returning home - I intend to ans. it soon
you ask what I think of Miss Davis' letter -
I think this - It is a well written letter, but the
author is very forward, & is evidently fishing
[written on the left-hand side of the page]
for the position - Mr. Osgood sends it because he knows how he has said it
done some things that more painful to Mary & he thinks we may know of it & he
[written along the right-hand side of the page]

the parts

Warwick, July 25, 1875

My dear Sister,

                        I do not hear a

word from you, & perhaps you wait
for me to write? If so, you must
not, any more; for I desire so much
to hear from you often; do write
often, if only a few words, that I 
may know you, & your family are
well, or otherwise---

  We have all been to Church, &

I am so tired this evening, I cannot
write well, or interestingly I fear---
Brother John, Mary, & myself went---
I was up & dressed at 6, & worked
as hard & as fast as possible, so I could
go this A. M.

   Breakfast to get, & the usual morning

chores, as feeding chickens -- carrying
hay & water to the Bossy --milk to
skim & pans to scald-- sweeping &c till
the time was at hand that we must
get ready for church, so as to be in
season --- As soon as I got home
the supper must be got ready, & then
the night chores come on one after
another, & now it is nearly 9 o'clock--
[written on left-hand side of the page]
Our garden looks well -- string beans in plenty now--
My Strawberries yielded a bountious Harvest--
[written sideways above the date]
The "Denverites" 
quite well at
last account
from them --
gave into camp
in the Mountains
wish you & the 
boys would
come & make
me a visit.
Tell Chandler
& Rhoda I
wish they 
would come
with their
children--
Now "good night"
with best of 
wishes for you all--
Your Affec.
sister, Emily
Completed

Jonas has been playing the melodeon
& Mary sang - I like to have Jonas
play, because he always plays those
dear old tunes, Danford used to
sing so much -
I went to the cemetery between the
services - O dear, you do not know how
strange it seems sometimes when I am
beside Danford's & Mary's grave - It seems
as though they must  come forth from
their hiding place & be with us again in
person - Where, O where, have their
dear spirits fled? Why do they not
give me some inkling of their [abiding?]
place, when I so long to have them?
Did your slips of Mary's plants live?
Of mine, the rose & "feather-fern" lived.
The rose has grown wonderfully & now
has a bud, but I shall take it off -
The feather-fern has grown into a lovely
handsome plant & is in full bloom -
I am going to put the plant & pot on her [grave?]
And the rose she gave me a 
year ago, when I was there, has been
in blossom 2 weeks or more - It is a 
beautiful blush rose, & I am reminded of Mary
every time I look upon those plants!
I am going to try to get a slip from
each I started for you -
Do you hear anything farther from
Mr. Osgood or his family since that
letter you sent us? I have not heard
a word excepting at the time of the
Unitarian Convention at Springfield
[written along the left-hand side of the page]
Please write very soon much love to the boys
how sad for them now they have no aunt
Mary.
[written along the right-hand side of the page]
John thought by commencing early he could do all the [haying?] himself -
Completed

in June - At that time he was there,
& Mrs. Libby & Mrs. McKim went -
Do you suppose it was arranged
before hand?I am sure I do not
know, & there is no way of finding out!
Samuel went to Church today for the
1st time - last week there was a 
church meeting & I suppose a reconcil-
iation - I have not yet heard what
was said or done, but his being at
Church makes me think the matter
settled -
Do you know of Maria's situation?
She did not wish me to mention
it, but everyone about here knows
of it, & you must sometime of
course - Do not let her know I
have given you hints - you may
tell Rhoda, if you both will keep
it to yourselves till you hear of it
legally! (some 4 or 5 months, I should 
judge) -
Alma has finished her school & is
at home - possibly, the wedding may
have to be deferred?
Samuel has a fine field of rye - 
What do you see & know of James?
Mary says he is at Hudson, at work
for Chandler! James has not wrote
to me since you were here, & Mary
does not let me see his letters, or
tell me about him or his affairs -
[written along the left-hand side of the page]
John thought by commencing early he could do all the haying himself - 
he don't want a machine to mow it because he cannot do so much pitching at one time.
Completed

I wish you would tell me all
you know of him, & his affairs.
I did not know that Helen & George
had gone to Denver till our towns-
people told me! After I knew of 
it from this source, then Mary
condescended to speak of it -
These children wrong their
mother continually, but I pray
that patience & forbearance may
be given sufficient unto the end -
You must not speak of this
will you, to any one? & burn this
as soon as you have read it -
will you heed this desire, please?
or it would only make a bad
matter much worse if it were to 
be know, & the children still
more obstinate, if they knew I told
you! 5 long years of this opposition
I sometimes imagine God suffers
it to be, for my discipline! that
is, I mean He takes this way to
wean me from them - perhaps I
have thought too much of my
children - & if so, God's will be done
if good to us all, can come from an
estrangement for a season -
But, Oh dear me, how hard!
Mary is going to Hudson soon, &
Berlin; but she seldom tells me of
her plans, & I know the least of
anyone usually - John is doing
[written along the left-hand side of the page]
the haying - he is not strong & can only do a little each day -
he commenced the 1st of July & has not got it half cut yet - 
[written along the top of the page]
My weakness & varicose vein have been
troubling for some days & it is hard standing 
or being on my feet -
Completed

Warwick Apr. 23d 1877
My dear Sister Abby
I am so
hurried I scarcely have time
to write a decent letter so
will you accept a hastily 
written one?
Sam'l & Maria have been
here & told me some things
concerning Mr. Osgood's claims
upon our Sister Mary's property,
which is so different from the
information I had gathered
from what you have told
me, & believed, and the letter
I rec'd from Judge Dewey, I feel
it a duty to let me work stand
still, & I take the time to acqu-
aint you of the new developments.
Now I wish to tell you & Chandler
this matter confidentially &
I desire you both to ans. by return
mail? 
Sam'l says Leslie Green is
going to Hudson today to see if he
can buy Chandler's colt, & whether
Completed

or not he has any other business
Sam'l did not say - but after what
he said about having an ad-
ministration upon Mary's
property & that he sent for C-
to meet him at Athol Saturday
I thought perhaps Leslie had
some other business also -
But this much certain, I desire
you & C- to not let Leslie know
a particle about this matter
in any shape or manner for
it would make food for the
gossips, & be blazed about all
over town -
I told Mr. Dewey in the letter
I wrote him, Mary's note was
secured by mortgage, for so I
had understood it but Sam'l
says it is secured by a warranty
Deed, subject to the claim
of the Greenfield bank - consequ-
ently Mary's note property was real
estate, & not "personal property."
Mr. Dewey in all probability knew
how it was from Mr. Osgood, &
why should he write me it was
personal property if it was real
estate, even if I did tell him
[written along the left-hand side of the page]
Are you & your family & Chandler's family well? & have you been
well all winter? It is beautiful weather here - frogs peeped Apr. 4th!
May flowers
the 15th!
much love to all
Completed

wrong about it by mistake?
or why should he tell me it could
be settled in "the other District
except in the one in which she
last resided" when Sam'l says
Lawyer Field & Judge Conant (our
county probate judge) said Mr.
Osgood has nothing to do with
it, neither can he administer
upon Mary's property in
this state?
Has Mr. Osgood, & Judge Dewey, been
cooperating together in order to
blind us so as to have the time

found out that he cannot put a stop

& that he can reach them only through
an Administration or Mary's property
Consequently desires to have an Ad-

not blame Sam'l for wanting a chance to

poor Mary's hard earnings gulped
up by the lawyers (as it will be if Sam'l
[written along the left-hand side of the page]
I do not know whether you see Greenfield paper so I will 
enclose an item I have cut from my last paper of Apr. 16th showing forth
Conn. laws
Completed

& Dea. Barber can have the management
in order to secure 2 or 3 acres of land
already skinned -
Sam'l said he had asked Chandler
to take out a letter of Adm. & he had declined
He has never mentioned the subject
to me until now, & says you & Chandler
will acquiesce with whatever he & I can
agree upon - I object to Dea. Barber as
Adm. on our sister's property - He has no
right, whatever, to the Adm'n - And other
reasons why he should not be you will
understand, I am sure?
I have consulted with Mr. James
Goldsburg, & he is of the same opinion, but
does not wish to say much or commit
himself, but wishes to see Mary's property
come back to her family instead of
being holden as it now is! Our con-
ference was confidential, & now
Abby & C- don't you betray it to any one.
Mr. G- says he right of Adm'n belongs
to me, & favors my doing this duty in-
stead of the Dea.
Now if it shall appear that Adm'n is
necessary, shall the Adm be Dea. B- or
will you allow me ot serve you
Sam'l seems in hot haste now &
says it must be done at once, which
will be the 2nd Tuesday in May. I
believe that a hearing can be obtained
at Northfield - it seems that some
decision from us must be given
& if I have the opportunity I shall expect
honest judge Conast can fix all this
right for us, if he can be allowed to.
I cannot stop to write any more now
but you & C must tell me what you
desire by return mail - your affec.

[written along the left-hand side of the page]
Is Mary Tyler at Hudson? if so, tell her to tell me what her address

[Emily]
Warwick Apr. 26th 1877
Dear Sister Abby,
Yours of the 25th 
I have just rec'd and many thanks for 
your promptness, for there is no 
time to be lost. I feel a great 
relief, somehow, in reading your 
letter, because I know now you 
fear just as I do about the matter. 
Sam'l and Deacon Barber went to 
Athol Monday & carried all their 
papers to show Lawyer Field, & 
have a consultation. The result 
of which I have not yet learned. 
I shall go up in the morning 
& if Sam'l is disposed to tell me 
particulars, I will write them in 
this & not send til Sat. Morning.
I have not mentioned the 
subject to a soul except Mr. 
J. Goldsburg & told him as little 
as possible - I tho't best to ask him 
some things, that he could tell 
one about as well as a Judge 
or Lawyer, & he promised not to tell. 
There are two facts prominent 
& they are these (just at this time). 
If what Mary left, does not belong
Completed

The Dea. is intending to 
unless we oppose it. 
It is quite late, & I cannot write 
as well when I am so tired, 
but if I can't, it is better than 
to not write at all.
Perhaps you & C- may object 
to my taking out a letter of 
adm? If so, I want you to say 
so unhesitatingly. 
If you cannot or will not, 
either of you, & I shared, I 
want you to promise me to stand 
by & assist me in all the 
ways you an. 
Mrs. Green & Maria visited 
here yesterday & very early in 
the P.M. they tried to introduce 
the subject about Mary's things 
& I did not & would not, say 
the first word - I understood 
the game & changed the subject 
as often as they introduced it, 
& not one word did they get out 
of me.
But the day I went to the P.O. 
to carry your letter Maria said 
she thought it would be rather 
hard for her father to serve as 
Adm for he was getting old &c - 
I tho't then, & still think she 
said it to draw me out, but she 
didn't that time.
It surprises me to learn from 
your letter, that Sam'l (rather 
Maria) did not ask C__ to Adm'n 
because I surely understood 
them that they did & C_ declined. 
I will find out about it tomorrow 
but shall not let them know 
what I have learned through you. 
I think Charles should be told 
about this matter as soon as we 
know anything definite and serious, 
& consulted even though so far away. 
[written along the left-hand side of the page] 
I wish you or Chandler would do it for already have so many letters to write 
& so little 
time I 
have 
to do it 
nightly.
Completed

to Mr. Osgood. I do not want 
him to have it, or deceive us 
either. & I do not want Dea Barber 
to have anything whatever, to 
do about the settlement of it. 
For most assuredly. Well, 
I better not write it. You know 
what I would say, & if not, I can 
tell you some time. I do not 
desire the responsibility by 
any means, but I shall do 
what I can to Keep Mary's 
little, from evaporating. 
& prevent the Lawyers from 
swallowing it, until after a 
settlement & discussion. 
Then will be the time, for 
each to do as they like with 
their portion. 
Don't you see, if a law-suit 
is commenced, it will come 
right out of Mary's money, 
& the excuse will be self defense 
or in other words, protection of 
the property? & I have not the 
least sympathy with such 
doings!
I did not tell Sam'l in 
plain words that I should object 
to the Dea. but told him just as 
you say, "it is a wrong thing to 
go outside the family with the 
matter" - I am perfectly willing 
you or Chandler should Adm'n 
but I am not willing Sam'l or
Completed

the Dea. should under the cir-
cumstances - Or, if you or C--- 
wanted serve with me, I would 
rather than serve alone, & 
I would do what I could -
or, if we could all agree upon 
some one to do it for us & 
would like that way, but am 
decided positively so that I 
will not be so stupid as to

Write me at once & tell me

Probate is the 2nd Tuesday I think 
at Northfield & I verily believe

My very dear sister Abby
As you will see, many days
have passed by, since I wrote
the enclosed, but as I have
time to write a long letter now

to come here - I asked her
if they should go, & she tho't it
quite an undertaking - said
she had ans.'d your letter &c -
Josie told me if they did not
go to Hudson they should

on with this job till

because I can do
it, & can be perse-

[illegible]
plain - I some-

could not be put off, I commen-
ced an investigation - I went

I copied all I found at

kept on the search & study -
Yesterday went to Northfield
& got a pile of old deeds of
Widow Harry Ball - James
Ball, (Harry's grandfather) was
the Proprietors agent & told
much of 
their land in this town -
I have gone to the very
bottom, & got at true boundaries

midday sun! - The original
line is 2 or 3 times father
north from the pond than

Chandler & Sam'l are both mistaken
as I told them, & as the old Corn-[illegible]
Monuments show for themselves
Somebody, sometime has taken

line, & an acre of wood & timber
from the north side, I should
judge - The mysterious corner
are all myths! there will be some
squirming when they are shown
the true ones I suppose -
If I could only have the assistance
of some energetic man only a few

rest

invite Alma & Leslie & her

This copy which is Judge Dewey's reply to my letter
of inquiry will show you at once the purport of the
questions I asked & my honest intentions, nothwith-
standing Mr. Osgood's abusive letter to Hudson
at my expense, in which he so unfairly sets
forth my motives -
You know very well what motives prom-
pted me, & that the only means I had at hand
for obtaining information was by writing.
And everyone knows, it was just as right &
honorable for me to ask questions, & seek in-
formation as for Mr. Osgood or anyone else.
After receiving this I did not suppose anything could be done
at present -
Emily-

to do so, & is necessary

The time limited in
this State for Granting
Adm. is Seven years.
The Estate can be settled
in no other District
except the one in

the District of Granby.
Yours Truly
Watson Dewey
Probate Judge for the

[Emily Tyler]
Warwick Sept. 10th 1880
Dear Sister Abby,
It is a  long time
since you or I have written each other,
& truly, there is so much to write to 
tell you all I wish that you may be
posted quite up to the present time,
why, it seems like a mountain,
like an everlasting job, & I have no
time & can't, & there it is, & there it
will have to be, for ought I know
Now I wish to tell you all about
Charles & his children - 
Of our dear good Rhoda, so sudden-
ly taken from her family, & all of us.
And Patience - Dear me, it seemed
as though we were all going -
Charles, Chandler, & William all
bereft of their companions just as
we were - we can sympathize & pity,
[written sideways across the top of the page]
Emma cannot go to school 
here after snow comes -
it is too far, & 
she cannot go through
the snow either - 
But I think Frederic
could go it in the
winters - It is so 
different now Danford 
is gone!
I cannot harness
up & take children
to school in the
cold & snow
you know, & [summer?]
ought to have good
school privileges -
Please write as
soon as you
receive this, &
not delay for
a single mail.
Completed

but every sorrowing heart knows the
depth of its own sorrow - just think
how every one of us but Sam'l are in 
sympathy for like afflictions - But Abby,
how lonely it seems to think of Rhoda as
so far away & gone, all gone to this
life she was living here, & to her family
& us - I suppose Chandler & Eva have
told you all the particulars concerning
Rhoda's sickness, death, & burial - I am
glad to have Rhoda at rest in our cemetery, 
as she & Danford are buried very near to
each other - The foot of Danford's grave
is near to the head of Rhoda's -
At sunset Sunday Sept. 12 -
Well I commenced this letter & was 
interrupted & I'll try again but the
same fate is likely to end this effort
as I have to leave off so often - so
I'll just touch upon the most important
items & be sure of them - One item
is concerning Charles & his children - They
came on about the 1st of May - Chandler
Completed

had to borrow Eva's school money
to send them to come on with, & as you
can see, it would have stopped her
college course, of course, if her mother
had not have died - There was some
over $20 left when Charles got here, but
Charles has had it, & used it nearly all
now, I believe - They all stopped at
Sam'ls but the same day all the children
came here & I have provided for & done for
them quite beyond my means, & strength
They were as destitute as you can pos-
sibly imagine - besides their destination
they are children that have brought up
themselves! so all my duty has not
been simply to feed & clothe them, but
try to correct their faults & learn
them how to do for themselves -
I must say, there has been great
neglect on the part of their parents.
for instance, Walter is almost 16
& a bright, active, smart boy, naturally,
& can only get on poorly in reading
Completed

& cannot begin to tell the multiplica-
tion table -- now this out not to have
been, & there is no good reason for it for
they have had schools, &  Charles Lin-
sely could have taught his children --
I tell you this is wrong -- Walter has
been born into the world , & for this 
neglect, must be a sufferer in con-
sequence, all through life -- & then the
children's manners have been sadly
neglected -- but they are all quick
to learn, & see and willing to be told
have to do & want to do as others do.
Nellie being the youngest will be the

I hired  Walter ti do my farm work
[top page written perpendicularly]

& paid him $10
per month
a stout boy to

if he had a 
man to have

very much he

& as yet has not learned like Walter

His health has been improving every day

than his, & I am quite thin of

       If Charles was likely to be worse or

Warwick Apr. 8th 1880
Dear Sister Abby,

   Yours of Mar. 29th was duly 

rec'd & your words of caution noted. I have 
not considered Dea. B a "Saint" for years, as 
you know, & I think, with you, these days 
"Saints or Sinners" all need watching -
Well, Apr. 6th is past, & I have had a chance 
yesterday, & today, to breathe more freely - Still, 
the matter of Mary's property is not just as 
it should be, [ran?], as I believe, but I cannot 
hinder it - As you will see as I report progress,
I had told the Dea. as I should surely redeem 
for myself, & in behalf of you Charles, & Chandler 
unless he did assign it over, & the Tax title 
foreclose in our hands Sam'l supposed he 
could redeem it, & told me if I undertook to 
do it, he should forbid it - Well, I got counsel 
of Judge Bacon of Worcester, & he said any one 
of the Heirs could redeem, but  no one could
[written sideways across the top of the page] 
May come home 
last week, & returns 
next Monday. 
Reed has been 
having Measles 
at New York City -
Albert Moore 
has married 
again - A lady 
from Illinois 
I believe. 
Oh Abby I thank the 
Lord that awful 
Tornado did 
not touch my 
house - 
But, our house
came near being 
burnt up! As I think 
I have told you in a 
previous letter -
[note below salutation] 
with love 
from 
your affectionate 
sister -
E.R. Tyler

for any one but himself without Power of

sisted I should not, but keep still! & all would

Warwick Mar. 24th 1880
Dear Sister Abby,      [under salutation] I am glad you are so near. P.O. I wish I was.
Thank you for your prompt re-
turn of letters & documents. it makes so much 
relief from anxiety off  - I have written Charles

boys go for some competent person to come to 
his house & make the thing easy as possible -
I thought perhaps if I didn't he might feel 
that he had been left out & worry about it.

come up by Sam'ls request - he may come but I 
think doubtful.

Republican.

1/2 the wife's property in real estate, since 1877.  
Mary died in 1875 & the land as then, governs, 
which gives the husband no interest in any 
real estate. Now the consequence of landed prop-
erty by Deed is real estate, & Mr. Osgood is cut off 
in this direction (Judge Bacon's decision)
Mary put all her money into that farm, 
inconveniencing herself by so doing, but her 
desire to save the homestead so great, she did it - Mary 
bought the farm with the Bank incumbrance & rec'd 
a warranty deed of Harvey Barber, Chas. Gale & Jasper 
Gale. - the balance on the farm over & above the 
Bank incumbrance, was her pay in full, and 
was sufficient to cover her claim.
Then what need of a note being given? for 
certainly you will see it made a twofold
Completed

3d
obligation for Sam'l to meet, if he should try to buy her out, which is wrong, a 
mistake, an oversight at the very outset.
Sam'l sees it now, but neither he or Mary did 
at the time of the transaction - If Mary had lived 
she & Sam'l would have amicably righted this
error. Mary's 1st note was all right & proper, but 
no interest in the farm? the 2nd note uncalled 
for, out of place, because she had already rec'd 
all there was to give, by deed & her full equiv-
alent.
But however wrong, it was given, & Mr. Osgood 
has got it, which is the ugly thing to be met, & 
got rid of - there are 2 ways that seem plausible 
in which this difficulty will probably be met - 
1st Sam'l has had no title or deed of the place for 
15 or 16 years whatever, & not the owner. Mary bought of 
other parties! The note was between Sam'l & Mary 
but don't you see, he had no farm to secure it then or any 
other property - so the farm was virtually Mary's. 
If the time had come that Sam'l could have 
raised the amount of money to have paid 
Mary all she put in, why then, Mary could have 
sold to him in the same way she bought it.

that is, with the Bank incumbrance & now good 
reason why there might not have been an 
understanding between Sam'l & Mary that he should

facts to face, there is nothing to sustain any thing like 
a bond, & no bond, there cannot be any mortgage 
upon real estate, even though Sam'l had been 
the previous owner & sold to Mary! Which by the way 
he did not, So the note & farm cannot be united or made 
to fit together - Hence this condition of things dethrones 
all claim for a bond as security for the note Mr. 
Osgood holds, as I view it, & as I think it will turn 
With this condition of things. Judge Bacon's advice 
was, that we redeem,  & not let our hold slip. 
Afterwards Mr. O can prove & sustain 
the claim, why then, the judge suggests that the 
heirs buy him off, or do any other way for the best
good of the heirs -
Mr. O to get a foothold has got to produce a

There was a something, that was unnameable 
& that something is nowhere, & nobody can tell of it 
one word correctly, & it isn't to be produced because 
No one had any knowledge of it upon my word & honor if under oath, I could not tell one word of it - how then came Mr. 
O prove anything - & here is the only chance of Mr. O
[written along the left-hand side of the page] 
I hope you will write if anything suggest itself -

pencil.

the matter - I do not believe the 
life your are living, is very good for 
giving the rest you need, & must 
have, or succumb. Well, we can 
sympathize, for I am very poorly, 
compared to what I was when you

been a hard one for my strength,

in Mary's adopt-

what an idea
when she has

who told you 
so? -
Mary sends 
love - but 
all the
