Warwick. Mass. Sept. 11th 1893
My dear sister Abby.

               And so you have taken 

yourself off to Chicago! So far, far away, I fear 
we are never more to meet? & why were you 
so long ans'g my 2 letters? I was bound to 
do as you do, & wait as long! Now then, 
the 1st thing to relate is to tell you of the 
birth of my little grandson! His birth 
occurred Aug. 23rd & his weight 9 lbs 11 oz! 
Mr. Elisha Bassett visited us last week, 
& he told us Anna & the babe were doing 
nicely - Mr. Bassett is 82 & he seems 
very well - how we all are growing old! 
I have been ill several weeks & am quite 
poorly now - Aug. 6th I had an attack of 
inflammation of the kidneys & bladder, & I 
am far from well - I have suffered 
intense pain almost continually ever
Completed

since the attack - The pain was so great I was obli-
ged to send for a Doct. having tried all my 
remedies that I knew about - When the Doct. 
came he gave me opiates to take, & Suppos-
itories of opium to apply. The sharp edge of 
the pain would be dulled of course by the use 
of opiates for the time but the trouble does not seem to 
be arrested at all - Some days I have less 
pain, & think I am better, & without any 
known cause for it, the 1st I know, the 
pain all comes on again, & all is to go over 
with again. My hardest pain follows when there 
is a passage of water. I am drinking a tea 
made of cleavers now, but I fear it is not suffi-
cient of itself to remove the disease, whatever it 
may be, wholly. It is now nearly 6 weeks I have 
been shut-in, & some of the time confined to 
the bed or lounge, & can get relief only from 
hot applications. Have you ever had similar 
ailments? & if so, what remedies gave relief 
& a cure?
Well, how are you liking & enjoying your new 
home? It will be very pleasant for you to have
Completed

Geo. & Arthur with you - We have new neighbors 
on the John Stearns place - the house has been 
vacated for 3 or 4 yrs. - & there is a change of 
neighbors at the Henry Hastings place - the part 
that Henry's mother had has continually changed 
occupants. The fact is they cannot get on with 
Melinda & Everett only for a short time, so 
sell & clear.

 Since the financial troubles commenced,  & the 

manufacturing establishments (many of them) 
in this vicinity have shut of employment & 
employees, the vacated farms have had a 
"boom" - One Agent has sold more than 20 
since spring, in this town! But many of the 
new comers are foreigners! One family of 
Swedes in this neighborhood - they seem like 
nice people, however -
Brother Lorin has been poorly all summer, & it is 
intimated that his mind is weakening --Jona. 
has been ill this summer also, & he took refuge 
in the Keene City Hospital to be cared for - 
Farnum (Juda's husband) has sold his place in 
Keene & has gone West to visit his son Lorin -
Completed

The family is quite broken up - Abbie teaches & 
boards - Maude is at the Keene Hospital pre-
paring herself to be a "Professional Nurse"- 
Emilie & Wm was at Arkleby Hall with 
his unmarried sister when their last 
letter was written - but preparing for a trip 
through Scotland - They both very well - 
Mary keeps herself busy with society 
affairs - Quite recently she got up an enter-
tainment which was much enjoyed by all 
the participants - Rev. Mr. Thatcher of Newton 
is our minister - Every year our Society have their 
annual picnic in the summer season, & this year 
-by way of variation, Mary started a Surprise par-
ty for our Minister! The Entertainment was in 
the evening at Hotel Hall - The Hall was trimmed 
& decorated, & furnished for the evening in 
drawing-room style - Rugs & Art Squares, laid 
upon the floor - Lace Curtains at the windows -
Completed

2nd
Draperies & pictures hung on the walls - tables 
& stands all about the Hall, with covers, & lamps 
& vases of flowers - & plenty of chairs - After 
the people arrived, the 1st thing to be done was 
to send a delegation to the ministers & escort 
him to the Hall - The surprise to him was 
quite genuine - There was social chat-
singing-Tableaux - Grand "Cake March" with 
a prize for the best performer (The 3 min-
isters the judges) & refreshments of cake & 
coffee, & Ice creams, constituted the Enter-
tainment - Of course all took hold with Mary 
to help on with the entertainment - & all were 
more than satisfied with the success & 
pleasure the entertainment afforded - 
All our society were included, but outside of 
our society only those by special invitation - 
150, or more, were at the party - & so it goes 
with Mary - I did not go, as I was not well 
enough to be out evenings "galavanting" around
Mary staid all night with Clara Jones - 
James Goldsburg's oldest son, Doct. James 
Goldsburg, married Barnard Fishers eldest
Completed

daughter Grace, by his 2nd marriage. They 
went to China - He, as Medical Missionary -
Last spring he died of typhoid fever - His 
widow & little 4 yrs. old son have just found 
their way home again - His wife expecting to 
become mother again in Nov! How hard her 
lot in life has seemed to me since her 
husband's death - It was a very heavy blow 
to both families.
Cousin Leonora came to Nashua a year or 
more ago, & I have heard that last winter 
she had a stroke of Paralysis - I do not know 
how severe it proved to be -
Cousin Mary Mayo Crosby died last March 
aged 74 yrs -
Cousin Abby is quite poorly - thought by 
some that she had consumption - she lives 
at the Hastings farm which became hers when 
her husband died - Her daughter Mary lives
[written sideways across the top of the page] 
with her 
& Mary has the care 
of a granddaughter 
two years old that 
she keeps with 
her at Abby's - 
So Abby has lived 
to be great grand-
mother!! 
Sam'l & wife & girls 
all well as usual - 
Nellie rides over to

She came with me to

the day last week but 
I was not well enough

Mary sends love -
Kind remembrance

Warwick, Mass. Dec, 23d 1897
My dear sister Abby,

            It is a long time 

since I have written you, but it is 
only doing as you do! You have made 
me wait such unaccountably long periods 
to hear from you. I tho't you might as 
well do some of the waiting! In fact, it is 
no longer an easy task to write letters -
Or rather, to set myself about it perhaps! 
But I cannot allow this opportunity to go 
by & not extend to you my congratulations 
for your new found daughter! I feel 
it is best to be so, notwithstanding you 
& Arthur will have to yield up much of 
Geo's future to his chosen companion for 
life! I hope this new alliance will prove 
a most happy union for all - Extend 
to Geo. & his bride my best wishes for their
Completed

present & future happiness, with the 
"Season's Greetings".
My dear sister, it is impossible to let 
these holy days go by & not be much reminded 
of my far-away, seldom seen, sister Abby - 
It is a great comfort to me to know you 
are in the land of the living, while so 
very many of our friends & acquaintances 
of childhood years, have passed on to the 
other life.
Mr. Jones was 90 yesterday, & Mr. Goldsburg 
101 yrs next month! They too, will soon join 
the No. "over there" - Mary was at the Village 
yesterday P.M. & Clara invited her to join 
them at tea-time & share her father's (Mr. 
Jones) birthday-cake - Mrs. Jones has just 
passed her 75th birthday. 
My little granddaughter, Grace Emilie, 
is 8 yrs old today! Goes to school, & is quite 
a "Miss." Danford, 4 yrs. last Aug. is a nice 
little fellow - Anna & the 2 children gave 
us a 6 weeks visit last summer - James 
[written sideways along the top of the page] 
I wish you 
would 
write &

your family 
& children.

& covered

but not

There is a genealogy Moore
Family being compiled & soon to be
published ---  The author is a Mr. Barnard
of New York --He is a descendant of Capt.
Mark Moore, our grandfather's brother--
Some of Mark Moore's children settled in 
Rouse's Point & Ticonderoga, N. Y. & the
Moores & Barnards now in N..Y. state,
are their descendants--
Some more than a year ago letters came 
from N.Y.  state, inquiring for the Moore
brothers that settled in Warwick, &
especially so, of the Capt. Mark Moore
family -- No one of Warwick people was
able to give much information & the letters
were handed over to me to ans[wer] & recently
I have rec's 2 letters from Mr. Barnard
asking my assistance.

 4 brothers came from Sudbury, Mass.

in 1770, & were among Warwicks [sic] early
settlers -- They were Jonathan, Mark,
Samuel & John -- John, and our grandfather
Completed

2nd
& the youngest of the 4 brothers. Their 
father's name was Daniel.
Jarvis Moore is a descendant of 
Jonathan Moore & is going to fill out 
the record for his branch -
Mrs. Green's mother was Harriet Moore 
& daughter of Samuel Moore - Julia 
Green, Proctor will furnish the record 
of her grandmother's branch -
I am to furnish the records of our 
branch - descendants of John Moore - 
The Mark Moore descendants are chiefly 
in N.Y. state, but Mr. Barnard wishes 
me to give all the items I can of their 
Ancester that lived here - You 
will remember the Capt. Mark Moore house 
across the road from Ed. Stevens house? 
A low cottage house, & we used to pass it on 
our way going to Uncle Mark's. It was

the home where Sam'l & Washington Moore

Warwick, Mass. May 21st 1900.
My dear Arthur,    

         I have written your 

mother a birthday-day letter, & now write 
you, that I may thank you for the copyings 
from the Sudbury Town-records, & for 
my share in the Photos you sent - I 
have been enjoying the photos immensely.
Last Dec. the Moore Genealogist wrote me 
urging strongly to send him what I could in 
connection with the Moore records. I felt it to 
be an arduous undertaking, to classify, arrange, 
& write out my collection correctly & satisfacto-
rily, because I was feeling so poorly, but I 
have done it , & it is a great relief to my mind.  
It took me many, many weeks to do it, but I 
wanted to do it for the benefit of the present 
generation & those that may follow.
When you were here, I told you when I got

Warwick, Mass. July 10 - 1900 -
Dear sister Abby -
Why are you not here 
as we have so long expected? What is it 
that hinders your starting? As you dd 
not come last year, it was a foregone 
conclusion that you would come this! 
& I have been expecting you every day 
since the middle of May! & looked, 
& looked, & looked for you ever since!
I have written you & Arthur about it, 
& talked over your coming with Geo. & his 
wife, & told them to let me know at 
once after their return - I was so very 
disappointed when I learned Geo. had 
started East without you, but when he 
got here he helped me over it somewhat 
in telling me he tho't you & Winthrope 
H4
Completed

would come after his return. I knew 
the day he would reach home, & my look-
ing for you commenced again. the 3d 
day after, & have looked in vain everyday 
since! We have had several dates set 
that we tho't you would be here sure! 
& we have done extra cooking for your 
especial benefit also! Still you do 
not come. Now, when you receive this 
won't you write & tell me your plans, 
& what I may expect. If you will come, 
& when? You see I don't want you to come 
& find me away for the day, as Geo. did! 
notwithstanding it was the 1st & only 
day I have been from home this year! 
I want to know the exact time for 
continuing my looking, & not have 
any unnecessary looking to do! I want 
you to ans. & then I will know what I 
may depend upon. You know we all want 
you to visit us, & you wrote me you 
were feeling better than last year.
Completed

I am no longer young, & never can be 
again, & no doubt our days are all 
numbered, so it is well to improve 
those at hand. Just make yourself 
a good cup of tea before Answering this 
& you will decide to come. I find it 
reduces the mountains to mole-hills 
for me, oftentimes!
Sam'l came with the milk this 
morning, & he seems better, & is look-
ing better since the warm weather 
came. & he seems more cheerful too. 
The haying season is close at hand, & 
the fleet-footed summer months will 
soon be gone!
I did want you to see my lovely roses 
in full bloom, & now they are already 
withering & fading!
I have sold me grass standing, & will 
have no bother with the haying.
I had hoped to see Emilie this summer. 
Eva said when she returned from

We enjoyed Geo. & his wife's visit ex-

Waltham March 9 1854
Dear friend

                I was surprised on looking over 

your letter this evening to find it dated as 
far back as March 23, almost a year since. 
My intentions continually have been to write to you 
in reply. But you know good intentions do not 
always avail anything, especially where the intend-
er is "shiftless". (You know who says that word.)
I was happy to hear from you, and hope you 
will forgive this long delay in writing.
We hear from our friends in your vicinity, 
but very seldom, and when we do tis very accepta-
ble. I am thinking Jane will soon be old enough 
to conduct the correspondence of both her father, 
and mother. 

  I anticipate visiting Warwick this summer. 

It seems a long time since I was there, but I 
remember very well the pleasant time I enjoyed 
while there. O what a delightful shower that
Completed

was when we visited at your house, don't you 
remember how we were drenched with the rain? 
And those blue-berrys-- how good -
I shall want to visit the old Homestead, 
for I never can loose my interest there. 'Tis 
to me a sacred place. I do not wish to live 
there now, but shall ever love it as my 
old home, as being connected with the dearest 
memories of my childhood. No other place will 
ever seem like that - and yet I do not wish 
to convey the idea that I am not as happy 
now as then, on the contrary, the longer I 
live, the more I find to enjoy. There are Sources 
of enjoyment to a matured mind, that 
in childhood we are Strangers to. Would 
you go back to your baby-hood again if 
you could?
I have recently been to visit my mother 
and sister & in Worcester. I need not tell 
you that my visit was pleasant, for you will 
readily guess that. Weather was not very well 
then and was obliged to keep mostly in the house.
Completed

She thinks of visiting her children up your 
way, another summer. Patience seems 
to enjoy her new home very much. She lives 
over the store where Wm is in business, 
which make it convenient for him and 
pleasant for both. Little Mary is Patience 
Tyler right over again, and our Eva is 
Laura Tyler over again. So you see those 
characters are likely to be perpetuated.
Eva says she is Aunt Rhoda's girl. I 
think of making her my heir. You know I 
will want somebody (If that is wicked I'll 
take it back) I took her to Worcester with 
me. I want to see Danford's children very 
much. I thought Reed was the cunningest 
when I was there.
Laura has three children who take about 
all her time - her health is pretty good now. 
Brother David idolizes his little Clara. 
I tremble for him if he should loose her. 
She seemed to be his "all in all".
Lorin is very busy, so we hardly see him, 
excepting holidays.
Completed

[Rhoda 1854]
I commenced taking lessons on Pianno last 
summer, I find it rather trying to my pa-
tience but am willing to persevere - how 
do you succeed? I thought you was coming 
down our way last summer. I shall look 
for you yet, and expect a visit from you 
when you do come.
So Chandler is married - much joy to 
him and his - Is Samuel's tenement unoccu-
pied yet? and how is yours? It must 
be very pleasant to you all to be so near 
each other--under the same roof.
Where is that minister that so much desired 
to have an medium in his family & perhaps 
he has got one now. By the way do you 
experiment any in the Spiritual line now?
We are having a course of Lyceum lectures 
here this winter. Some of which are exceedingly 
interesting - and others are equally, dull and 
tiresome.  Our benevolent Circle meet once 
a month, and spent afternoon and evenings 
generally fully attended.
Give my love to your Mother and family. 
I shall be happy to hear from you again and 
will try to be more promt in a reply.
yours affectionately Rhoda
[Tyler]

Waltham Oct 29 1855
Dear friend Abby--
Do not fear that your letters will not 
be acceptable to me. I am always happy to hear 
from my friends, and I flatter myself that you 
are one of that number.
Soon after the reception of your letter, we left 
here for a Short tour to the West - visited Sara-
toga Springs on our way to McDonough, (where 
David Randall's brothers live) and on our return 
stopped at New York for a Short time.
We intended to go to Niagara, but Laura's health
failed, and she did not feel able to go so far - 
So we gave up that idea.
I enjoyed the visit very much, only I felt very 
anxious about Laura. She was quite out of health 
and is still not well (now don't go to surmising 
anything that is not modest)
At Saratoga we had a glimpse of fashionable 
life, though most of the gentry had left for hour 
before we got there. We Saw quite enough 
to convince me that I would not like to take 
their place.  I saw some Southern families 
with their attendant Slaves - and wished 
that they might take wings and fly away.
Completed

Brother David and wife were here Thursday 
on their return from your place, said they 
had a fine time. Helen Said you had 
closed your School, so I suppose you are at home 
playing the dutiful daughter.
As to the "preparations" you speak of - I am 
preparing for nothing in particular, only to keep 
warm next winter. My progress in Music is 
very slow I assure you. I don't like it and 
consequently most any excuse suffices to delay 
practice. So when I go to Warwick again 
I hope you won't ask me to play.
Patience as here last Summer, and spent 
three weeks with us. Of course, we were very 
happy together so long. Mother was here a 
part of the time. I anticipate visiting them 
next winter, about lecture time. I want to 
hear some Spiritualist lectures, attend their 
circles etc. Worcester, you know, is a great place 
for Spiritualism, and I must tell you I am 
taking quite an interest in the Subject. 
I have been reading Judge Edmonds book on 
Spiritualism. Gave you read it? if not I 
wish you would. I think it is deeply interesting. 
I wish Danford and Emily would read it too.
Completed

I wish I could see you Abby, and talk 
with you. I wish I could be as good 
a medium as you were once. I am afraid 
you did not improve your gift--did you?
I think there must have been great rejoicing 
in your family on the return of your brother 
Charles after so long an absence. Byron says 
he looks sick.
Lorin comes out to spend the sabbath with 
us now, every week, which makes it pleasant for 
him and us. He had gone into business for 
himself now, and his time is about all taken 
up.
Our new meeting house is nearly completed, 
and we are talking about getting up a 
fair, on the opening of the vestry--if so 
I shall have to make something for the occasion.
I attended the great National Agricultural 
fair, recently held in Boston. Saw cows, swine, 
sheep and horse-racing, the latter was a little 
exciting, but the others I had seen before, unfor-
tunately.
I shall look for you next winter, and will 
try to make you as comfortable as I can if you 
will come. I shall be very happy to hear from 
you at all times. Yours affectionately Rhoda G Tyler
Completed

Waltham Dec. 21/56
Dear Abby--

  I have commenced a new system 

of letter-writing,-and that is to write 
to some one of my friends every Sunday 
evening - and this evening I will devote 
to you.
I need not tell you that your letter 
was very acceptable, and brought joy 
to my heart- though I began to fear 
you had forgotten your promise to write.
I am sure you did not enjoy your 
visit here more than I did. It was 
very fortunate for me that your visit 
occurred just at that time, when I 
was wanting company so much.
I find myself, quite frequently, rehearsing 
in my own mind--our sayings and doings 
at that time- and sometimes I laugh--
I do-- Will you come again next 
year?
Completed

I tried to tell you in Jane's letter 
where we live now. Did you get the idea? 
We do not live near the river as we 
did when you were here. and tis 
not so pleasant around us here as 
there, but still we like to live here 
better, tis more retired, and we can 
be alone if we please. I don't 
like to live with everybody, always.
Laura's health is very much better 
now and in answer to your question 
I will say, I think Doct. York's prescri-
ptions, and good influences were bene-
ficial to her. I don't think there 
was any miracle bout it at all, 
only simple and natural remedies 
were applied. He makes no pretentions 
to miracles.
As to Spiritual matters, I do think 
just as much of them as when you was 
here, and should be sorry to be deprived 
of the comforts and consolations they 
bring.
[written along the left-hand side of the page] 
Ralph Waldo Emerson lectures here this week I expect a treat 
Please write soon - Ask Jane if she has received a letter 
from me.

[Tyler] [(Emily's niece)]
And now one or two questions to you. 
Has that event occurred, which was 
either to convince, or confirm your 
unbelief in Spiritual intercourse? 
I feel "kinder" anxious to know. 
Another question, Has your acqua-
intance with that Mr. Somebody 
"out west" ripened into anything more 
than friendship? Now don't blush 
but own up--like a woman--
I think he must want a companion 
by this time and who so suitable 
as you?
I suppose you and Mary are taking 
lotts of comfort this winter "not 
keeping school."
We have been engaged for a time 
past, in getting up a fair (We Baptist 
folks) to help pay for the Organ. 
The proceeds amounted to $160, so we 
shall have to try again or do some other 
way, for tis not paid for yet. I think 
tis hard work and poor pay -
[written along the left-hand side of the page] 
I think you will guess who writes this, if I don't sign my name 
Love to all my friends -
Completed

My friend, Miss White is here yet 
teaching school. I believe you rather 
liked her, and she said as much 
of you. She is expecting to go to 
her "dear" at the West in the Spring 
if fortune favors.
I must tell you that Martha Jones 
who was keeping house for Mr. Keyes 
is now married to the [Saure?], and, 
Mothers those two children. You will 
remember seeing her at the new house -
She seemed pleased with the change 
in her affairs.
Do you know my brother Lorin is married? 
they spent Thanksgiving day with us
I like her very well, and think I 
shall like her better in acquaintance. 
I think of going to Worcester soon 
to see my Mammy - tis too cold 
now to think of going to Warwick 
this Winter.
My room is on the north side of 
the house and cold as Greenland 
this weather - for we are having horrid 
cold weather here.
I forgot to tell you I heard that Mr. 
Hill's sermon you speak of, but he failed 
to convince me that it was wrong to 
commune with our departed friends. 
Did not Jesus commune with departed 
Spirits on the Mount, Moses, Elias and 
others? The Bible is full of similar instances
[written along the left-hand side of the page] 
If those old laws are binding on us now, then we have no right to
